**Chapter Thirty-Eight: The Highest Virtue Does Not Feign Virtue**
"Superior benevolence acts, yet without contrivance."

The Meaning states: "Minor favors are not yet trusted." This refers to the words of Cao Gui to Duke Zhuang of Lu, as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the tenth year of Duke Zhuang. In the first month of that year, the duke defeated the Qi forces at Changshao. Before the battle, Cao Gui requested an audience.

His fellow villagers said: "Those who feast on meat devise the strategy—why inquire further?" Cao Gui replied: "Meat-feasters are coarse, incapable of far-reaching plans," and so he entered to seek an audience.

The duke asked how to engage in battle. Cao Gui answered: "That which sustains life through clothing and food, I dare not monopolize, but must share with others."
Cao Gui responded: "Minor favors do not extend universally; the people will not follow."
The duke said: "Sacrificial animals, jade, and silk—I dare not exaggerate, but must act with sincerity."
Cao Gui replied: "Minor sincerity does not inspire trust; the spirits will not bestow favor."
The duke said: "In cases great and small, though I cannot examine each in detail, I must judge with compassion."
Cao Gui said: "This is an attribute of loyalty; with this, one may fight a single battle." He then requested to accompany the duke. The duke rode with him, and they joined the battle at Changshao.

As the duke was about to sound the drum for attack, Cao Gui said: "Not yet."
After the Qi forces had beaten their drums thrice, Cao Gui said: "Now."
The Qi army was routed. The duke prepared to pursue, but Cao Gui said: "Not yet." He dismounted to inspect the chariot tracks, then ascended the crossbar to survey the field, declaring: "Now," and they pursued the Qi forces.

After victory, the duke asked the reason for his actions. Cao Gui replied: "Battle relies on courage. The first drumbeat rouses the spirit; the second, it wanes; the third, it is exhausted. When theirs was spent and ours full, we prevailed. Yet great perils are unpredictable—I feared an ambush. When I saw their tracks in disarray and their banners drooping, I knew we could pursue."

"Superior propriety acts, yet with contrivance."

**Commentary:** It establishes safeguards against crookedness.
**Exegesis:** Ritual is instituted to prevent the people from straying into crookedness. Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue follows.

**Exegesis:** In the twenty-sixth year of Duke Zhao of *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, Yanzi replied to Duke Jing of Qi: "Ritual as the foundation of the state stands alongside Heaven and Earth. When the ruler commands and the minister is reverent, when the father is kind and the son filial, when the elder brother is loving and the younger respectful, when the husband is harmonious and the wife gentle, when the mother-in-law is compassionate and the daughter-in-law obedient—this is ritual. When the ruler commands without transgression, the minister is reverent without duplicity, the father is kind and instructs, the son is filial and admonishes, the elder brother is loving and friendly, the younger is respectful and compliant, the husband is harmonious and righteous, the wife is gentle and upright, the mother-in-law is compassionate and yielding, the daughter-in-law is obedient and graceful—this is called the perfection of things."

The Duke said: "Excellent! From this day forth, I have heard of the supremacy of ritual."
Yanzi replied: "What the former kings received from Heaven and Earth, they established for their people—thus were the former kings supreme. Therefore, in governing the world, ritual is of the utmost urgency."

**Chapter Thirty-Nine: "Formerly, Those Who Obtained the One"**
When the lords and kings obtained the One, they became the standard for all under Heaven.

**Exegesis:** *The Spring and Autumn Annals* states: "The kings of today are the emperors of antiquity." Before Yao and Shun, all were called *Di* (Emperor). When Shun abdicated to Yu, Yu, in humility, claimed his virtue did not match that of the *Di*, and thus abandoned the title *Di* to become *Wang* (King). It is also said that when Yu died, he abdicated to Yi, but Yu’s son Qi dwelled on Mount Ji. Qi was worthy, so the feudal lords abandoned Yi and paid court to Qi. Though Yu had the reputation of abdicating to Yi, the people of the world all turned to Qi. Qi, deeming his virtue inferior to the Five Emperors, thus styled himself *Wang*. From then on, all adopted *Wang* as their title. When Qin unified the world, devoured the feudal lords, and stood alone as the sole power, it drew from the Three Sovereigns above and encompassed the Five Emperors below, combining them into the title *Huangdi* (Emperor). Today, the royal rank of *Wang* stands above the five noble ranks. Han law stipulated that none but the Liu clan could be *Wang*, and none but meritorious ministers could be *Hou*. From then on, the custom continued: the emperor’s many sons became *Wang*, with the eldest legitimate son as heir apparent. Since the Zhou dynasty ruled the world, the sons of kings were called *Wangzi* (Prince), and their grandsons *Wangsun* (Lord). In our dynasty’s established law, the emperor’s grandsons and nephews are made *Junwang* (Commandery Prince), with the heir designated *Siwang* (Hereditary Prince). Those of other surnames who rendered service are enfeoffed as *Wang*, sometimes granted honorific titles, or made *Junwang*, yet none hold territorial authority.

Heaven cannot remain clear.

**Exegesis:** During the *Yuan Kang* reign of Emperor Hui of Jin, the ruler’s virtue declined, and Heaven displayed calamitous omens. The sky split for several *zhang*, rumbling with sound—this was the loss of the harmonious Dao. From then on, the Western Jin fell into chaos, and Emperors Hui and Ai both suffered its consequences.

Earth cannot remain stable.

**Exegesis:** The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: In the second year of King You of Zhou, on the day *Xin-You*, the three rivers of the Western Zhou trembled, and Mount Qi collapsed. In the 242 years of *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, there were five earthquakes. There were also the collapses of Mount Liang and Mount Shalu, and the strange portents of speaking stones. From the Qin and Han dynasties onward, such events are too numerous to record—great ones submerged cities, while lesser ones toppled houses.

The spirits cannot retain their numinosity.

**Exegesis:** The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records: In the twelfth year of Duke Xi’s reign, in the seventh month, a spirit descended at Shen, and the Duke of Lu offered it a feast. King Hui of Zhou’s He-nei historian Guo asked: "What is the reason for this?" He replied: "When a state is about to rise, a luminous spirit descends to witness its virtue. When it is about to fall, a spirit also descends to observe its corruption. Thus, some gain spirits and prosper, while others gain spirits and perish. The Xia, Shang, and Zhou dynasties all experienced this. Guo’s virtue was cold and insincere—it was about to perish." Later, the state of Guo was indeed destroyed.

In the past, the River Spirit wrought tyranny, taking women from the people. Ximen Bao cast the witches into the river, and the harm ceased.

The valleys cannot remain full.

**Exegesis:** The Venerable Lord Laozi said: "When the Yi and Luo rivers dried up, the Xia perished; when the Yellow River ran dry, the Shang perished. In the year *Xin-You* of King You of Zhou, the rivers dried and the mountains collapsed—this was the omen of Zhou’s fall. Destruction came within ten years, for ten is the limit of fate. When the number reaches ten, the cycle is complete. In the eleventh year, *Geng-Shen*, the Western Zhou was destroyed by the Quanrong, and King Ping moved east."

The feudal lords and kings cannot retain their lofty nobility.

**Exegesis:** Among the feudal lords were Duke Ling of Jin (Yi Gao), Duke Zhao of Song (Chu Jiu), Duke Yi of Qi (Shang Ren), and Duke Ling of Chen (Ping Guo). Among the kings were Tai Kang of Xia, Wu Yi of Shang, and You and Li of Zhou, as well as Huan and Ling of Han.

**Subcommentary:** Heaven generates the myriad things, but only humans are endowed with spirit.

**Exegesis:** This is from the *Book of Documents*, in the "Great Declaration" chapter.

Thus, the noble takes the humble as its root.

**Subcommentary:** The people are the foundation of the state, as the *Odes* says: "A joyful and kind-hearted lord."

**Exegesis:** This is from the *Book of Documents*, in the "Five Sons’ Song" chapter. "Joyful and kind-hearted" is a phrase from the *Odes*, in the "Great Elegantiae" section, from the "Dong Zhuo" ode.

Therefore, feudal lords and kings refer to themselves as "the solitary," "the bereft," or "the unworthy."

**Subcommentary:** "The solitary" and "the two or three ministers" grieve over their lost plans.

**Exegesis:** "The solitary" and "the two or three ministers" refers to the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, seventh year of Duke Zhao: In the second month, the Viscount of Chu completed the Zhanghua Terrace and wished to invite the feudal lords to its inauguration. The inauguration is the ritual of offering the first sacrifice upon the completion of a palace. Minister Wei Qijiang said: "Your servant can secure the presence of the Duke of Lu." Wei Qijiang came to summon the Duke, who declined, saying: "In the past, our late lord Duke Cheng commanded our minister Ying Qi: ‘We have not forgotten the friendship of our predecessors. We will send Hengfu to oversee the state of Chu, to pacify its altars and bring peace to its people.’ Ying Qi received this command at Shu and swore an oath, recorded in the second year of Duke Cheng. Since then, we have upheld it without fail, and it has been passed down through our ancestral temple. From our late lord Duke Gong, we have stretched our necks northward, yearning day and night. The succession has been handed down through four kings—namely, Gong, Kang, Jia’ao, and Ling. Yet no gracious favor has reached us, save for Duke Xiang’s condescension to attend our mourning. The solitary and the two or three ministers grieve over our lost plans, with no leisure to tend to the altars, let alone cherish the virtue of our lord. Now, if you would deign to step forth with jade footsteps and honor our humble lord with your presence, bestowing your radiant grace upon Chu and fulfilling the pledge of the Shu campaign, thereby conveying your lord’s benevolence—then our humble lord would have already received your kindness. How could we dare hope for the Shu campaign? The spirits of our former lords would truly rejoice in this, not merely our humble lord. If you do not come, your servant will inquire about the date of your journey. Our humble lord will present gifts of silk and meet you at Shu to seek the blessing of our former lords." The Duke was about to go when he dreamed of Duke Xiang’s ancestral spirit. Zimu said: "The Duke will not go after all." When Duke Xiang went to Chu, he dreamed of the Duke of Zhou’s ancestral spirit leading the way. Now that Duke Xiang’s spirit truly leads, you should not go. Zifu Huibo said: "Go. Our former lord never went to Chu, so the Duke of Zhou’s spirit led the way. Duke Xiang went to Chu, and now his spirit leads you. If you do not go, where will you go?" In the third month, the Duke went to Chu. The Earl of Zheng received him at Shi’s Bridge. Meng Xizi served as his second, but could not assist with ritual propriety. Upon reaching Chu, he could not respond to the welcoming rites at the suburbs. In the fourth month, the Duke was feasted at the Xintai, where long-maned attendants were appointed to assist, and fine bows of great curvature were presented. Later, the Duke regretted this, and Wei Qijiang, hearing of it, came to see him. The Duke told him, and Wei bowed in congratulation. The Duke asked: "Why congratulate me?" He replied: "Qi and Jin have long coveted this, but our humble lord had no one to give it to—until it was passed to you. You must prepare defenses against our three neighbors and guard this treasure well. How could I not congratulate you?" The Duke grew fearful and made amends. This illustrates that Duke Ling of Chu was untrustworthy, which is why he did not endure.

In the ninth month, the Duke personally went to Chu. Meng Xizi, being ill, could not assist with the rites. Thereupon, he began to study and teach, allowing those who could perform the rites to follow him. He then ordered Nangong Jingshu and his subordinates to study ritual with Confucius.

Confucius and Jingshu traveled to Zhou, where they inquired about ritual from Laozi.

*Commentary: The use of "Guaren" (the humble one) follows the precedent of former lords who deemed "Guaren" a worthy designation.*
*Exegesis: As explained in the thirty-third section of the preceding passage on "he who knows others is wise," it will not be repeated here.*
*Commentary: The use of "Bugu" (the unworthy one) follows the precedent of despising those who lack sincere virtue.*
*Exegesis: In the eleventh year of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Qin and Jin sought reconciliation and were to meet at Linghu. The Marquis of Jin arrived first, but the Earl of Qin refused to cross the Yellow River. The Earl of Qin (Duke Huan of Qin) encamped at Wangcheng and sent his grandee, Shi Ke, to swear an oath with the Marquis of Jin (Duke Li of Jin) east of the river. Xi Luo of Jin swore an oath with the Earl of Qin west of the river. Fan Wenzi said: "What benefit does this oath bring? The purpose of oaths is to establish trust through words, and meetings are the beginning of trust. If the beginning is not followed, how can it serve as a pledge?" The Earl of Qin returned and betrayed Jin. In the thirteenth year, on the *wuwu* day of the fourth month, the Marquis of Jin sent Lü Xiang to sever ties with Qin. By then, Duke Huan of Qin had already sworn the Linghu oath with Duke Li of Jin, yet he also summoned the Di and Chu, intending to lead them in attacking Jin. The feudal lords thus drew closer to Jin. Lü Xiang addressed the Earl of Qin, saying: "The people of Chu detest your inconsistency in virtue and have also come to inform us, saying: 'Qin has betrayed the Linghu oath and now seeks an alliance with us. We hereby proclaim to august Heaven, the Supreme Emperor, the Three Lords of Qin, and the Three Kings of Chu: Though we have dealings with Jin, we ally only with what benefits us. We despise those who lack sincere virtue and thus make this known to punish disunity.' The feudal lords have all heard these words, and so, with aching hearts and gnashing teeth, they draw near to us. We, in turn, have led them to heed your command, seeking only goodwill. If you graciously favor the feudal lords and grant them an alliance, we shall support and pacify them before withdrawing. If you do not bestow this great kindness, we, being unworthy, cannot lead the feudal lords to retreat. We humbly lay this before your attendants, that they may deliberate upon it." Jin’s Yue Shu, Shi Xie, Han Jue, and Zhao Zhan led the four armies. Xi Kui drove the war chariot, and Yue Zhen served as the right guard. On the *dinghai* day of the fifth month, the Marquis of Jin, leading the allied armies of the feudal lords, fought the Qin forces at Masui. The Qin army was routed, and Cheng Qiang of Qin, along with the officer Ru Fu, were captured. This illustrates that the Earl of Qin broke his oath, that Qin was at fault and Jin was in the right, and that defeat was the consequence.*

*Chapter Forty-One: The Superior Man Hears the Dao*
*The Dao advances as if it retreats.*

Here follows the translation:

---

The *Yijue* states: Li Yiqi begged for food among the mortal realm; Yin Changsheng endured humiliation in the marketplace; Hou Daohua concealed his traces as a hired laborer; Huangfu Ta feigned illness in the wooded hills; Shengzi feigned madness; and Master Hu concealed his brilliance. All these exemplars humbled themselves and diminished their aspirations, only thus soaring toward the heights and merging with the True.

**"Vast virtue appears insufficient."**

*Commentary:* The excellent merchant...
*The Yijue* states: The *Records of the Grand Historian* recounts that Confucius, accompanied by Nangong Jingshu, journeyed to Zhou to inquire of Laozi about ritual propriety. Laozi said: "The men of whom you speak are now but dust and bone; only their words remain. I have heard that the excellent merchant conceals his treasures as if his store were empty, and the noble man of abundant virtue bears the countenance of a fool. Shed your arrogance and excess desire, your affected manner and extravagant ambition—none of these benefit your person. What I tell you is just this."

**"The great square has no corners."**

*Commentary:* "Polished yet dyed black..."
*The Yijue* states: This is from the *Analects*, in the "Yang Huo" chapter.

**"Great vessels are slow to complete."**

*The Yijue* states: That which equips things for use is called a "vessel." In the ninth year of Duke Ding of *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Yang Hu returned treasured jades—the *xiahoumin* jade tablet and the great bow *Fengfu’s Luxuriant Might*—recording the event as "obtained vessels." Generally, to obtain vessels is called *de*, and to obtain their use is called *huo*. Thus, a vessel is that which equips things for use.

**"Thus, some things are diminished yet gain."**

*Commentary:* The *Book of Documents* states: "Fullness invites diminishment..."
*The Yijue* states: These are the words from the "Counsels of Great Yu" in the *Book of Documents*.

**"The strong and overbearing do not meet their proper end."**

*Commentary:* The Immortal Yan...
*The Yijue* states: Yan Zun, styled Junping, of Shu Commandery, often practiced divination in the marketplace of Chengdu, subtly transforming people through the Dao. When questioned with improper intent, he invariably restrained and corrected them with the principles of yin and yang. Daily, he earned a hundred coins before closing his shop and lowering the curtain, composing the *Zhigui* (Pointers to the *Dao and Its Virtue*) in fourteen scrolls.

**Chapter Forty-Three: The Softest Under Heaven**
**"The teaching without words."**

---

**Commentary:** The nine schools and the hundred masters.

*The Yijue* states: The "nine schools" are as follows, according to the *Book of Han*: The Daoist school enables one to unify the spirit, act in accord with the formless, and suffice for the myriad things. Its methods follow the great harmony of yin and yang, shift with the times, respond to things with transformation, and are rooted in purity and emptiness for self-preservation, humility and softness for self-sustenance—this is the art of the ruler facing south.

The Confucian school, originating from the office of the Minister of Education, assists the ruler in illuminating moral transformation, tracing its lineage to Yao and Shun, modeling itself on Wen and Wu, and taking Confucius as its master to lend weight to its words. It is the highest in the Dao, and this is its strength. Yet it may lose its subtlety and become biased, or bend with the times, straying from the root of the Dao, merely seeking to please the crowd and accommodate others—such are the flaws of later, perverse Confucians.

The School of Names originates from the Spring Office, where ranks differ and rites vary accordingly. Confucius said: "It is essential to rectify names"—this is its strength. But when taken to excess, it becomes mere hair-splitting and sophistry.

The School of Diplomacy originates from the office of the Messenger. Confucius said: "One sent on a mission to the four quarters cannot be expected to improvise replies," and also: "A messenger! A messenger!"—meaning one must weigh affairs and adapt to circumstances, receiving commands but not the words. This is its strength. Yet when practiced deceitfully, it values cunning and abandons trust.

The Eclectic school originates from the office of the Counselor, blending Confucianism and Mohism, combining the Schools of Names and Laws—this is its strength. But when taken to excess, it becomes aimless and without a guiding principle.

The Agricultural school originates from the office of the Minister of Agriculture, sowing the five grains to ensure ample clothing and food. The *Great Plan* lists eight policies, the first being food—this is its strength. Yet when vulgarized, it seeks to make gentlemen till the soil alongside commoners.

The School of Minor Talks originates from the office of the Recorder of Popular Sayings. "Bai" means small grain; the ruler, wishing to know customs, established this office to gather street gossip and alleyway discussions. Confucius said: "Even in minor ways there is something worth observing, but pursuing them too far may lead to entanglement"—this is also the meaning of "the words of grass-cutters and madmen."

The Mohist school originates from the attendants of the ancestral temple, with thatched roofs and rough-hewn rafters, selecting worthy men and esteeming those who yield. The Yin-Yang school originates from the astronomical office and the theory of the Five Phases, leading people to excessive taboos and restrictions.

The Military school originates from the office of the Minister of War, serving to awe those who defy the law and manifest civil virtue, to annex the weak and attack the benighted, to curb disorder and pacify the four quarters—this is its might.

The "hundred masters" refer to those outside the Six Classics and orthodox histories who established their own doctrines and composed works. Since the Zhou dynasty, over a hundred individuals have set forth principles and written books, all called "Masters." "Master" is a general term for men; not daring to equate themselves with the Six Classics, they are all designated as "Masters," whether in treatises, records, or books. Some are named after their surnames, others by their era or title—examples include Master Yuchang, Master Zeng, Master Yan, Master Meng, Master Guan, Master Xunqing, Master Lulian, Master Lie, Master Zhuang, Master Gengsang, Master Wangsun, Master Yinwen, Master Gongsun Ni, *Master Lü’s Spring and Autumn Annals*, Deng Xi (also called Master Xishi), and Master Guigu.

**Chapter Forty-Four: Name and Life**
**Name and life—which is dearer?**

*The Yijue* states: Boyi died for benevolence, Nie Zheng died for righteousness, Weisheng died for trust, Jing Ke died for courage, Long Feng died for remonstrance, Wu Yun died for loyalty, Jie Zitui died for resentment—all achieved fame but lost their lives, their bones scattered, faces flayed, hearts carved out, burned by fire or drowned in water, eyes gouged by swords. They brought ruin upon themselves.

**Excessive love must lead to great loss; hoarding wealth must lead to heavy ruin.**

**Commentary:** The harm of prizing jade is like holding a jade disk; the tomb-robbing of the refined is only for the pearls within.

*The Yijue* states: As for prizing jade, in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the tenth year of Duke Huan, Yu Gong’s younger brother Yu Shu possessed a jade. Yu Gong demanded it, but Yu Shu refused. Later, Yu Shu regretted it, saying: "There is a Zhou proverb: 'A commoner is blameless, but possessing a jade disk is a crime.' Why do I need this? It will only bring harm." He then presented it. Yu Gong further demanded his precious sword. Yu Shu said: "He is insatiable. If he is insatiable, it will reach me—I fear he will kill me." He then attacked Yu Gong, who fled to Hongchi.

As for the tomb-robbing of the refined, this is a saying from the Outer Chapters of the *Zhuangzi*.

**Chapter Forty-Five: Great Perfection Seems Deficient**
**Restlessness overcomes cold; stillness overcomes heat.**

**Annotation states:** The *Tian Yuan Jing* says: After the Beginning of Summer, the sun travels along the north of the earth, entering the ground shallowly, thus nights are short and days long—this brings heat. After the Beginning of Autumn, the sun travels along the south of the earth, entering the ground deeply, thus nights are long and days short—this brings coolness. The sun’s distance from the pole varies, giving rise to warmth, coolness, cold, and heat. Thus, cold and heat, restlessness and stillness, are the movements of yang qi.

As for the ruler who employs the Dao, governing through non-action brings order: his governance is still, and all things thrive; the state is secure, and the people are at peace. The four frontiers submit in allegiance; the five weapons lie unused. Clarity and emptiness congeal in tranquility; purity and silence abide in harmony. Deceit dares not encroach; violence dares not rage. Beacon fires remain unlit; war drums do not startle. Within the seas, all is serene—this is stillness prevailing.

When his transformative influence reaches its height, songs of praise resound in unison; reverence and deference flourish. The ninefold circuits harmonize; the four gates stand solemn. Ritual is established; music is composed. The worthy are elevated; the capable are employed. Ships and carriages converge in hope at his court; written laws and axle-tracks align with his governance. The eight frontiers gather in submission; the myriad regions hasten in allegiance. Heaven and earth respond in resonance; humans and spirits commune in harmony. All under heaven transforms in radiant accord with the Dao.

Within, there is no scheming through cracks; without, there are no neighboring states watching for openings. They sing of it, savor it, dance to it, and leap in joy—this is the achievement of stillness, governance, and non-action.

If, however, the ruler is restless and reckless, his ministers deceitful and cunning, stirring up arms and flaunting power and favor—mobilizing a million-strong army to ascend the Chanyu’s terrace, banners stretching a thousand *li* to cross the shores of the Pei and Liao—then the old and weak are pressed into labor, women compelled to transport supplies. The four seas seethe; the six directions convulse. When the people are exhausted, households dwindle, lives are uprooted, the wilds lie deserted, and ghosts wail by day—this is the consequence of restlessness prevailing.

**Chapter Forty-Six: When All Under Heaven Possesses the Dao**
**Annotation states:** When the sage rules the realm, he bears the ceremonial axe and faces south.

When shamans stand before and scribes behind, with diviners and blind musicians arrayed to left and right, one governs through non-action and upholds perfect rectitude. The Three Dukes attend court, the Three Elders reside in the academy, and the myriad officials fulfill their duties—cultivating civil virtue to embrace distant lands, spreading the transformative power of the Dao to nurture the people, so that customs become harmonious and peaceful, households flourish in ritual propriety, and tribute flows in from the four frontiers. The three borders see no military campaigns; shields and spears are upturned, warhorses retired to pasture, oxen returned to the plow. Then the people delight in tilling the soil, enriching the fields, and the harvests grow thick as clouds, with surplus grain spilling over the furrows. Should one deviate from this path, however, resentful enemies will invade in concert, warhorses gallop unchecked, and armor and weapons are once more put to use—such are the works of a realm without the Dao.

When all under heaven possesses the Dao, warhorses are sent back to fertilize the fields.

**Annotation states:** The ancients said: "The ruler is like a boat; the people are like water. Without the ruler, the people cannot be governed; without water, the boat cannot move. Boat and water depend on each other and cannot be separated even for a moment. Thus, the foundation of governing a state lies first in nurturing the people." When a ruler abides by the Dao, his guardianship extends to the four barbarian tribes; beyond his borders, there are no military incursions, halberds lie unused, and blades and arrowheads remain sheathed. Armor is set aside at the three borders, and fields are opened across the four wildernesses. Deep plowing and shallow sowing ensure that households are well-provided and the state grows prosperous. Food is the people’s heaven—its cultivation is the greatest of all tasks. As the *Record of Rites* says: "Man is the virtue of heaven and earth, the convergence of yin and yang, the meeting of ghosts and spirits, the finest essence of the five phases. Thus, when the sage establishes norms, he must take heaven and earth as his foundation, yin and yang as his starting point, the four seasons as his handle, the sun and stars as his markers, ghosts and spirits as his companions, the five phases as his substance, ritual propriety as his vessel, human sentiment as his field, and the four sacred creatures as his livestock. Therefore, human sentiment is the sage-king’s field. When the field of sentiment is cultivated through non-action, it approaches the Dao."

When all under heaven lacks the Dao, warhorses breed in the suburbs.

**Annotation states:** If a state is governed without the Dao, its rulers will expand borders and invade barbarian lands, leaving frontiers restless and conscription unending. Some, coveting spices, launch campaigns against distant Fan Yu; others, desiring fine horses, raise armies against Da Yuan. Bones pile in the barren wilds, blood soaks the grassy marshes, souls drift and scatter in foreign lands, and war chariots sink into the distant suburbs. Years stretch on in endless campaigns, and soldiers do not return even when the melons ripen. Transport never ceases, and the looms stand empty. The people resent, the state perishes—such calamities are not heaven-sent but arise from what should be deeply guarded against. How much better to keep the realm undisturbed, so that the feudal lords all submit, ruler and people harmonize, and superiors and inferiors protect one another. Then the strong have no outlet for their strength, the eloquent no stage for their words, warriors no edge for their blades, and the wise no chance to deploy their strategies. Swords and halberds are recast into plows and hoes; daggers are traded in the market for oxen to till the fields. Without action or conscription, the people preserve their lives and secure their futures.

No crime is greater than indulging desire.

**Annotation states:** The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records: "In the twentieth year of Duke Xi, Duke Xiang of Song sought to unite the feudal lords. Zang Wenzhong, a minister of Lu, heard of this and said: 'To follow others in fulfilling one’s desires is acceptable, but to make others follow one’s desires rarely succeeds.' This means bending one’s own desires to align with the greater good. The following year, the Duke of Song convened the Alliance at Lu Shang. Gongzi Mu Yi of Song remarked: 'When small states vie for leadership in alliances, they are fortunate to escape defeat.' That autumn, the men of Chu seized the Duke of Song and attacked his state—this illustrates how making others follow one’s desires strays from the Dao."

No misfortune is greater than covetousness.

**Annotation states:** The *Scripture of Laozi’s Repentance* states: "The first transgression is called a sin, also known as a fault. *Guo* (fault) means error. Committing 1,080 faults leads to calamity, and calamity is weightier than sin. Committing 1,260 faults leads to *jiu* (misfortune), and misfortune is weightier still than calamity."

**Chapter Forty-Seven: Without Leaving the Door**

**Commentary:** To concentrate the spirit and sit upright behind the screen.
**Annotation states:** *Ning* means stillness. *Duan* means solemn dignity. *Yi* refers to the dragon screen, meaning to lean against it—its form resembles a folding screen, painted with axe patterns, placed between the windows of the Bright Hall. In ancient times, the Duke of Zhou assisted King Cheng in the Bright Hall to receive the feudal lords, standing with his back to the axe-screen facing south, thereby establishing the proper positions of ruler and minister.

**Chapter Forty-Eight: Daily Advancement in Learning**
Daily advancement in learning.
**Annotation states:** *Learning* means awakening and enlightenment, referring to guiding one’s nature and emotions with the Way of the former kings to achieve understanding. In youth, one is benighted and unenlightened, unfit for learning; in maturity, one becomes obstinate and resistant, difficult to instruct. There are three timelinesses in learning:

First, the timeliness within the human body: after the age of thirteen, one may begin to study, as the *Record of Learning* states: "If restraint is imposed only after impulses arise, resistance will prevail; if learning begins only after the proper time has passed, it will be arduous and difficult to succeed."

Second, the timeliness within the year: the *Nei Ze* states: "In raising a child, at six years, teach them to count from one to ten, then to a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand, and to recognize directions—east, west, south, and north. At seven, boys and girls do not share the same mat nor eat together. At eight, they learn to enter and exit doors and take their seats at meals, always deferring to elders—this teaches them deference. At nine, they are taught the days of the month, the new and full moons, and the heavenly stems from *jia* to *gui*, as well as the six *jia* days. At ten, they go to external tutors, reside outside the home, and study writing and arithmetic. At thirteen, they learn the *Shao* dance and recite the *Odes*—recitation means reading aloud from memory. At fifteen, as youths, they learn the *Xiang* dance, archery, and charioteering. First, they perform the *Yue* dance, where the *yue* resembles a flute, held while performing the civil dance; later, they perform the *Xiang* dance, the martial dance. At twenty-four, they undergo the capping ceremony and begin to study ritual. At thirty, they marry, manage affairs of men, and study without fixed method. At forty, they enter office, offering counsel and devising plans. At fifty, they assume governance—this is the sequence."

Third, the timeliness within the day: learning is more readily absorbed when aligned with the seasons and qi. The *Royal Regulations* states: "In spring and summer, study the *Odes* and refined speech, for spring and summer are yang, and yang is light and clear—poetry and music are sounds, and sounds are naturally light and clear. In autumn and winter, study writing and ritual, for autumn and winter are yin, and yin is heavy and turbid—writing and ritual are affairs, and affairs are naturally heavy and turbid. Practicing light and clear studies in light and clear seasons, and heavy and turbid studies in heavy and turbid seasons, ensures that their qi resonate and are easily absorbed."

**Chapter Fifty: Birth and Death in the World of Humans**
Thirteen paths lead to the realm of death.
**Annotation states:** In receiving life, humans possess three karmic actions and ten evils. The three karmic actions are: first, bodily action; second, mental action; and third, verbal action. The ten evils are: bodily action has three evils—killing living beings, theft, and sexual misconduct. Mental action also has three evils—greed, anger, and delusion. Verbal action has four—divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, and frivolous speech. These three karmic actions and ten evils together make thirteen.

Restraint leads to life; indulgence leads to death. Each of these ten evils has four conditions, all rooted in afflictions. What are they?

For the sin of killing: four conditions—first, the being is truly alive; second, one conceives the thought that it is a living being; third, one harbors the intention to kill; fourth, one causes its life to end.

For the sin of theft: four conditions—first, the object truly belongs to another; second, one conceives the thought that it is another’s property; third, one harbors the intention to steal; fourth, one moves it from its original place.

For the sin of sexual misconduct: four conditions—first, the object is truly an improper partner; second, one conceives the thought that it is an improper partner; third, one generates the intention for sexual misconduct; fourth, the body experiences defiled pleasure.

For the sin of divisive speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who has been heard; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention to sow discord; fourth, one utters speech that creates division.

For the sin of harsh speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who is cursed; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention to curse; fourth, one utters abusive language.

For the sin of false speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who is deceived; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention to deceive; fourth, one makes statements that are untrue.

For the sin of frivolous speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who is deceived; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention for frivolous speech; fourth, one utters words that are improper.

In total, these ten evil actions comprise fifty-three conditions.

Traveling by land, one does not encounter rhinoceroses or tigers.

As the *Yi* states: The Xiao and Xiang Rivers flow from Mount Jiuyi and Lingling, where rhinoceroses and tigers dwell. In former times, Guo Wen of the Jin, styled Wenju, dwelt in Mount Dadi of Yuhang. He lived among tigers, and whenever he went to the city, the tigers would follow him. Someone asked him, "Sir, do you possess the Dao? How is it that these wild beasts are so tame and docile?" Wenju replied, "When humans harbor no intent to harm beasts, beasts harbor no intent to harm humans—what art is there in this? The tigers had no use for their claws."

The *Yi* further relates: As recorded in the *Biographies of Divine Immortals*, Liu Gang, styled Boluan, and his wife, Madam Fan, both attained the Dao of divine transcendence. When Gang served as magistrate of Shangyu, he traveled to Mount Siming and encountered a tiger. The tiger, seeing Gang, prostrated itself and dared not rise. Gang told his wife of this, and she went directly to the mountain, tied the tiger with a rope, and brought it home like a household dog. This was surely the power of virtue that subdued it.

**Chapter Fifty-Two: The World Has a Beginning**
To perceive the small is called clarity.

**Commentary:** "Worry, regret, and misfortune" are from the *Appended Judgments* of the *Book of Changes*.

**Chapter Fifty-Three: Let Me Be Firmly Resolved**
Girded with a sword of profit.

**Annotation:** On military preparedness—In the summer of the tenth year of Duke Ding’s reign, as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Confucius met with Duke Jing of Qi at Jiagu while acting as steward. He said: "Your servant has heard that where there are civil affairs, there must be military preparedness; where there is military preparedness, there must be civil preparedness. When the feudal lords cross borders, they must bring their officials in attendance. I request that you prepare your left and right marshals." Duke Ding consented. At the meeting site, an altar was raised with three tiers of earthen steps, and they exchanged courtesies according to ritual, ascending with bows. After the exchange of toasts, the Qi envoys sent men of Lai, armed and drumming wildly, to seize Duke Ding. Confucius ascended the steps in haste, stopping one tier short of the top, and withdrew the Duke, saying: "Send forth the soldiers! Our two lords meet in friendship, yet these barbarian captives dare disrupt it with arms—this is not how the Lord of Qi commands the feudal lords. Barbarians do not scheme against the Central States; Yi tribes do not disturb Hua; captives do not violate covenants; arms do not threaten amity. Before the gods, this is inauspicious; in virtue, it is a breach of righteousness; among men, it is a breach of propriety. My lord would surely not permit this." The Marquis of Qi, conscience-stricken, waved them away. After a while, the Marquis of Qi presented palace musicians, and actors and dwarves performed before the Duke. Confucius strode forward, ascended the steps, stopping one tier short, and said: "Commoners who deceive and insult the feudal lords deserve execution. Let the officials swiftly apply the law." Thereupon, the dwarves were slain, their limbs severed. The Marquis of Qi, terrified, showed shame. After the covenant with the feudal lords, he reproached his ministers, saying: "Lu aids its lord with the Way of the noble man, while you alone instruct me in the ways of barbarians, causing me to offend the Lord of Lu." He then returned the seized lands of Yun, Huan, and Guiyin to Lu—this is civil affairs and military preparedness.

**Chapter Fifty-Four: What Is Well Established Cannot Be Uprooted**
What is well established cannot be uprooted.

**Commentary:** Let models of conduct inspire trust.

**Annotation:** The *Book of Songs* in the *Greater Odes* states: "Take King Wen as your model, and the myriad states will place their trust in you." *Fu* means "trust." King Wen extended the Dao in his teachings, and the myriad states submitted in faith.

Cultivate it in your household.

**Commentary:** The *Book of Changes* says: "The household that accumulates goodness..."

**Annotation:** This is from the *Wenyan* commentary on the *Kun* hexagram.

Cultivate it throughout the world.

**Annotation:** When the Son of Heaven savors the Dao and delights in the profound, reveres Heaven and follows Earth, concentrates his mind in mysterious stillness, rectifies himself through non-action, unifies the standards of writing, and accepts tribute from distant lands, the Four Yi submit in sincerity, and the myriad states come to pay homage. The Dao extends without exception, and his virtue is universally pervasive. The ancestral temple is where the Son of Heaven conducts the affairs of state.

When virtue is universally bestowed—The *Xiang* commentary on the *Qian* hexagram in the *Book of Changes* states: "The dragon appears in the field; virtue is universally bestowed."

Observe the world through the world.

**Annotation:** If the ruler does not cultivate it, he becomes like Jie or Zhou.

When the people suffer in misery, the realm falls into rebellion, kin turn against one another as enemies, and lives are lost in bloodshed—even with wise ministers and valiant warriors, they cannot be put to use. Even with fortified cities and boiling moats, they cannot be defended. Though one may hold the noble rank of ten thousand chariots, the chance to live as a common man remains unattainable.

When the ruler cultivates the Way, he becomes like Yao or Shun: within the Four Seas, every household is worthy of enfeoffment; benevolence and kindness extend even to distant courts; and the calendar is proclaimed throughout the myriad lands. Though floods and droughts may strike, the harvest remains unharmed. Though armies march to war, the people bear no resentment.
