The passage refers to the *Ode "Wen Wang You Sheng"* from the *Major Court Hymns* of the *Book of Songs*. It speaks of King Wu establishing the capital at Haojing, performing the *Biyong* ritual, and drawing observers from all directions who, moved by his virtue, submitted to his rule.

He began by establishing names.
*Annotation:* Mountains and forests do not seek birds, tigers, or wolves, yet their lush density naturally draws them. Rivers and lakes do not seek fish, turtles, or dragons, yet their vast expanse naturally draws them. Kings and lords do not seek fame, yet through virtue, benevolence, and kindness, they naturally draw all to them.

**Chapter Thirty-Three: "He Who Knows Others Is Wise"**
He who knows others is wise.
*Annotation:* Formerly, Duke Xuan of Song bypassed his son Yuyi to enthrone his younger brother, who became Duke Mu. In the autumn of the third year of Duke Yin’s reign, as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Duke Mu of Song, gravely ill, summoned the Grand Marshal Kongfu and entrusted him, saying: "The late ruler passed over Yuyi to install me. I dare not forget this. If by the grace of the ministers I may preserve my life until death, should the late ruler inquire of Yuyi, what answer shall I give? I ask you to support him and uphold the altars of the state. Though I die, I shall have no regrets." Kongfu replied: "The ministers wish to serve Prince Feng." Duke Mu said: "That cannot be. The late ruler deemed me worthy to govern the state. If I abandon virtue and refuse to yield, I would undo the late ruler’s decree—how could that be called worthy? Should I not strive to illuminate the late ruler’s virtuous legacy? You must not forsake his achievement." Thus, he sent his son Feng to reside in Zheng, yielding the throne to Yuyi, who became Duke Shang. The noble man says: "Duke Xuan of Song may be called one who knew others. By enthroning Duke Mu, he ensured his own son would inherit—his command was righteous."

He who does not lose his place endures.
*Annotation:* The favored younger brother of Zheng, Duan, was insatiable.

Cao Gui responded: "Minor favors do not extend universally; the people will not follow."

Cao Gui replied: "Minor sincerity does not inspire trust; the spirits will not bestow favor."
The duke said: "In cases great and small, though I cannot examine each in detail, I must judge with compassion."

As the duke was about to sound the drum for attack, Cao Gui said: "Not yet."
After the Qi forces had beaten their drums thrice, Cao Gui said: "Now."
The Qi army was routed. The duke prepared to pursue, but Cao Gui said: "Not yet." He dismounted to inspect the chariot tracks, then ascended the crossbar to survey the field, declaring: "Now," and they pursued the Qi forces.

After victory, the duke asked the reason for his actions. Cao Gui replied: "Battle relies on courage. The first drumbeat rouses the spirit; the second, it wanes; the third, it is exhausted. chunks.original_text: 疏：曲为之防。 义云：制礼以防民曲也。 故失道而后德。 义云：《春秋》昭二十六年，晏子对齐景公曰：礼之为国，为国#1与天地并，君令臣恭，父慈子孝，兄爱弟敬，夫和妻柔，姑慈妇听，礼也。 君令而不违，臣恭而不贰，父慈而教，子孝而箴，兄爱而友，弟敬而顺，夫和而义，妻柔而正，姑慈而从，妇听而婉，谓之善物也。 公曰：善哉，寡人而今而后闻此礼之上也。 对曰：先王所禀於天地，以为其民也，是以先王上也。 则理世之道，礼为急矣。 昔之得一章第三十九 侯王得一以为天下正。 义云：《春秋》曰：今之王，古之帝也。 昔尧舜之前，皆称为帝，舜授於禹，禹以谦让，自云德不及帝，故去帝称王。 亦云禹没禅位於益，禹之子启居于箕山。 启贤，故诸侯去益而朝启。 禹虽有禅益之名，而天下之人皆归於启。 启以德不及五帝，乃自称王。 自是之后，皆以王为号。 至秦并天下，吞灭诸侯，独为一统，乃上采三皇，下兼五帝，通为皇帝之号焉。 今之王爵，居五等之上，汉法非刘氏不王，非功臣不侯，自是相承，以天子之众子为王，嫡为太子。 自周有天下，王之子为王子，之孙为王孙。 国朝定法，以皇帝之孙侄为郡王，承嗣者为嗣王，异姓有功者封王，或锡以美号，或封郡王，然皆无列土之位矣。 天无以清。 义云：晋惠帝元康年中，人君德衰，天示灾变，天裂数丈，殷然有声，是失冲和之道也。 自此西晋版荡，惠帝、哀帝皆罹其咎。 地无以宁。 义云：《史记》云：周幽王二年辛酉，西周三川皆震，岐山崩。 春秋二百四十二年，地震有五。 又有梁山崩、沙鹿崩、石言算妖异。 洎秦汉已降，不可胜纪，大则沦陷城邑，小则摧圯庐舍也。 神无以灵。

chunks.original_text: 义云：《春秋》僖主十二年七月，神降于莘，号公享之。 周惠王河内史过曰：是何故也？ 对曰：国之将兴，明神降之，鉴其德也。 将亡，神亦降之，观其恶也。 故有得神以兴，亦有得神以亡。 虞夏商周，皆有之。 虢多凉德，其将亡乎。 后号国遂灭。 昔河神为虐，娶女于人，西门豹投巫於河，其害遂息。 谷无以盈。 义云：老君曰：伊雒而夏亡，河竭而商亡，周幽王辛酉川竭山崩，周亡之征也。 亡不过十年，数之纪也。 数及於十，纪犹极也。 十一年庚申，西周为犬戎所灭，平王东迁是也。 侯王无以贵高。 义云：侯则晋灵公夷皋、宋昭公杵臼、齐懿公商人、陈灵公平国是也。 王则夏之太康、殷之武乙、周之幽厉、汉之桓灵是也。 疏：天生万物，惟人为灵。 义云：《书□太誓》篇文也。 故贵以贱为本。 疏：民惟邦本，《诗》云：恺悌君子。 义云：《尚书□五子之歌》也。 恺悌者，《诗□大雅□洞酌》篇之词也。 是以侯王自谓孤寡不谷。 疏：孤与二三臣悼心失图。 义曰：孤与二三臣者，《春秋》昭七年二月楚子成章华之台，愿与诸侯落之。 宫室始成，祭之为落也。 太宰蔿音委启疆曰：臣能得鲁侯。 薳音委启疆来召公，辞曰：昔先君成公命我大夫婴齐曰：吾不忘先君之好，将使衡父照临楚国，镇抚其社稷，以辑宁尔民。 婴齐受命于蜀，盟，盟在成二年。 奉承以来，弗敢失殒，而致诸宗桃。 自我先君恭王引领北望，日月以冀，传序相授，于今四王矣，谓恭、康、郏敖、灵王也。 嘉惠未至，唯襄公之辱临我丧。 孤与二三臣悼心失图，社稷之不遑，况能怀思君德。 今君若步玉趾#2，辱见寡君，宠灵楚国，以信蜀之役，致君之嘉惠，是寡君既受贶矣，何蜀之敢望。 其先君鬼神实嘉赖之，岂惟寡君。 君若不来，使臣请问行期，寡君将承贽帛而见于蜀，以请先君之贶。 公将往，梦襄公祖。 梓慎曰：公不果行。 襄公之适楚也，梦周公祖而行。 今襄公实祖，君其不行。 子服惠伯曰：行。 先君未尝适楚，故周公祖以导之。 襄公适楚矣，而祖以导君。 不行何之？ 三月，公如楚。 郑伯劳于师之梁。 孟僖子为介，不能相义，及楚，不能答郊劳。 四月，享公于新台，使长鬣者相，好以大屈之弓。 既而悔之，蔿启疆闻之，见公。 公语之，拜贺。 公曰：何贺？ 对曰？ 齐与晋越欲此久矣，寡君无适与也，而传诸君。 君其备御三邻，慎守宝矣，敢不贺乎。 公惧，乃及之。 此言楚灵无信，所以不终也。

**Exegesis:** The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records: In the twelfth year of Duke Xi’s reign, in the seventh month, a spirit descended at Shen, and the Duke of Lu offered it a feast. King Hui of Zhou’s He-nei historian Guo asked: "What is the reason for this?" He replied: "When a state is about to rise, a luminous spirit descends to witness its virtue. When it is about to fall, a spirit also descends to observe its corruption. Thus, some gain spirits and prosper, while others gain spirits and perish. The Xia, Shang, and Zhou dynasties all experienced this. Guo’s virtue was cold and insincere—it was about to perish." Later, the state of Guo was indeed destroyed.

In the past, the River Spirit wrought tyranny, taking women from the people. Ximen Bao cast the witches into the river, and the harm ceased.

The valleys cannot remain full.

**Exegesis:** The Venerable Lord Laozi said: "When the Yi and Luo rivers dried up, the Xia perished; when the Yellow River ran dry, the Shang perished. In the year *Xin-You* of King You of Zhou, the rivers dried and the mountains collapsed—this was the omen of Zhou’s fall. Destruction came within ten years, for ten is the limit of fate. When the number reaches ten, the cycle is complete. In the eleventh year, *Geng-Shen*, the Western Zhou was destroyed by the Quanrong, and King Ping moved east."

The feudal lords and kings cannot retain their lofty nobility.

**Exegesis:** Among the feudal lords were Duke Ling of Jin (Yi Gao), Duke Zhao of Song (Chu Jiu), Duke Yi of Qi (Shang Ren), and Duke Ling of Chen (Ping Guo). Among the kings were Tai Kang of Xia, Wu Yi of Shang, and You and Li of Zhou, as well as Huan and Ling of Han.

**Subcommentary:** Heaven generates the myriad things, but only humans are endowed with spirit.

**Exegesis:** This is from the *Book of Documents*, in the "Great Declaration" chapter.

Thus, the noble takes the humble as its root.

**Subcommentary:** The people are the foundation of the state, as the *Odes* says: "A joyful and kind-hearted lord."

**Exegesis:** This is from the *Book of Documents*, in the "Five Sons’ Song" chapter. "Joyful and kind-hearted" is a phrase from the *Odes*, in the "Great Elegantiae" section, from the "Dong Zhuo" ode.

Therefore, feudal lords and kings refer to themselves as "the solitary," "the bereft," or "the unworthy."

**Subcommentary:** "The solitary" and "the two or three ministers" grieve over their lost plans.

**Exegesis:** "The solitary" and "the two or three ministers" refers to the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, seventh year of Duke Zhao: In the second month, the Viscount of Chu completed the Zhanghua Terrace and wished to invite the feudal lords to its inauguration. The inauguration is the ritual of offering the first sacrifice upon the completion of a palace. Minister Wei Qijiang said: "Your servant can secure the presence of the Duke of Lu." Wei Qijiang came to summon the Duke, who declined, saying: "In the past, our late lord Duke Cheng commanded our minister Ying Qi: ‘We have not forgotten the friendship of our predecessors. We will send Hengfu to oversee the state of Chu, to pacify its altars and bring peace to its people.’ Ying Qi received this command at Shu and swore an oath, recorded in the second year of Duke Cheng. Since then, we have upheld it without fail, and it has been passed down through our ancestral temple. From our late lord Duke Gong, we have stretched our necks northward, yearning day and night. The succession has been handed down through four kings—namely, Gong, Kang, Jia’ao, and Ling. Yet no gracious favor has reached us, save for Duke Xiang’s condescension to attend our mourning. The solitary and the two or three ministers grieve over our lost plans, with no leisure to tend to the altars, let alone cherish the virtue of our lord. Now, if you would deign to step forth with jade footsteps and honor our humble lord with your presence, bestowing your radiant grace upon Chu and fulfilling the pledge of the Shu campaign, thereby conveying your lord’s benevolence—then our humble lord would have already received your kindness. How could we dare hope for the Shu campaign? The spirits of our former lords would truly rejoice in this, not merely our humble lord. If you do not come, your servant will inquire about the date of your journey. Our humble lord will present gifts of silk and meet you at Shu to seek the blessing of our former lords." The Duke was about to go when he dreamed of Duke Xiang’s ancestral spirit. Zimu said: "The Duke will not go after all." When Duke Xiang went to Chu, he dreamed of the Duke of Zhou’s ancestral spirit leading the way. Now that Duke Xiang’s spirit truly leads, you should not go. Zifu Huibo said: "Go. Our former lord never went to Chu, so the Duke of Zhou’s spirit led the way. Duke Xiang went to Chu, and now his spirit leads you. If you do not go, where will you go?" In the third month, the Duke went to Chu. The Earl of Zheng received him at Shi’s Bridge. Meng Xizi served as his second, but could not assist with ritual propriety. Upon reaching Chu, he could not respond to the welcoming rites at the suburbs. In the fourth month, the Duke was feasted at the Xintai, where long-maned attendants were appointed to assist, and fine bows of great curvature were presented. Later, the Duke regretted this, and Wei Qijiang, hearing of it, came to see him. The Duke told him, and Wei bowed in congratulation. The Duke asked: "Why congratulate me?" He replied: "Qi and Jin have long coveted this, but our humble lord had no one to give it to—until it was passed to you. You must prepare defenses against our three neighbors and guard this treasure well. How could I not congratulate you?" The Duke grew fearful and made amends. This illustrates that Duke Ling of Chu was untrustworthy, which is why he did not endure.

chunks.original_text: 九月，公自至楚，孟僖子病不能相礼，乃讲学，苟能礼者从之，遂令南宫敬叔已下学礼於孔子。 孔子与敬叔适周，问礼於老子焉。 疏：称寡人者，即先君以寡人为贤之例是也。 义云：如上经第三十三知人者智所解，更不重录。 疏：称不谷者，即不谷恶其无诚德之例是也。 义云：《春秋》十一年，秦晋为成，将会于令狐，晋侯先至，秦伯不肯涉河。 晋厉公、秦桓公也。 秦伯次于王城，使大夫史颗盟晋侯于河东。 晋郄荦盟秦伯于河西。 范文子曰：是盟也何益？ 齐盟所以质音致信也，会所以信之始也，始之不从，其可质乎。 秦伯归而背晋。 成十三年四月戊午，晋侯使吕相绝秦，时秦桓公既与晋厉公为令狐之盟，而又召狄与楚，欲导之以伐晋。 诸侯是以睦宾于晋。 吕相语秦伯曰：楚人恶君二三其德，亦来告我曰：秦背令狐之盟，而来求盟于我，昭告皇天上帝、秦三公、楚三王曰：余虽与晋出入，余惟利是亲，不谷恶其无诚德，是以宣之以惩不一。 诸侯备闻此言，斯是用痛心疾首，昵就寡人。 寡人率以听命，唯好是求。 君若惠顾诸侯，而赐之盟，寡人承宁诸侯以退。 君若不施大惠，寡人不佞，不能以诸侯退矣，敢尽布之执事，俾执事实图之。 晋乐书、士燮、韩厥、赵旃将四军，郗毅御戎，乐针为右。 五月丁亥，晋侯以诸侯之师及秦师战于麻隧，秦师败绩，获秦成羌及不更汝父，此言秦伯背盟，秦曲晋直，有所败也。 上士闻道章第四十一 进道若退。

In the ninth month, the Duke personally went to Chu. Meng Xizi, being ill, could not assist with the rites. Thereupon, he began to study and teach, allowing those who could perform the rites to follow him. He then ordered Nangong Jingshu and his subordinates to study ritual with Confucius.

Confucius and Jingshu traveled to Zhou, where they inquired about ritual from Laozi.

*Commentary: The use of "Guaren" (the humble one) follows the precedent of former lords who deemed "Guaren" a worthy designation.*
*Exegesis: As explained in the thirty-third section of the preceding passage on "he who knows others is wise," it will not be repeated here.*
*Commentary: The use of "Bugu" (the unworthy one) follows the precedent of despising those who lack sincere virtue.*
*Exegesis: In the eleventh year of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Qin and Jin sought reconciliation and were to meet at Linghu. The Marquis of Jin arrived first, but the Earl of Qin refused to cross the Yellow River. The Earl of Qin (Duke Huan of Qin) encamped at Wangcheng and sent his grandee, Shi Ke, to swear an oath with the Marquis of Jin (Duke Li of Jin) east of the river. Xi Luo of Jin swore an oath with the Earl of Qin west of the river. Fan Wenzi said: "What benefit does this oath bring? The purpose of oaths is to establish trust through words, and meetings are the beginning of trust. If the beginning is not followed, how can it serve as a pledge?" The Earl of Qin returned and betrayed Jin. In the thirteenth year, on the *wuwu* day of the fourth month, the Marquis of Jin sent Lü Xiang to sever ties with Qin. By then, Duke Huan of Qin had already sworn the Linghu oath with Duke Li of Jin, yet he also summoned the Di and Chu, intending to lead them in attacking Jin. The feudal lords thus drew closer to Jin. Lü Xiang addressed the Earl of Qin, saying: "The people of Chu detest your inconsistency in virtue and have also come to inform us, saying: 'Qin has betrayed the Linghu oath and now seeks an alliance with us. We hereby proclaim to august Heaven, the Supreme Emperor, the Three Lords of Qin, and the Three Kings of Chu: Though we have dealings with Jin, we ally only with what benefits us. We despise those who lack sincere virtue and thus make this known to punish disunity.' The feudal lords have all heard these words, and so, with aching hearts and gnashing teeth, they draw near to us. We, in turn, have led them to heed your command, seeking only goodwill. If you graciously favor the feudal lords and grant them an alliance, we shall support and pacify them before withdrawing. If you do not bestow this great kindness, we, being unworthy, cannot lead the feudal lords to retreat. We humbly lay this before your attendants, that they may deliberate upon it." Jin’s Yue Shu, Shi Xie, Han Jue, and Zhao Zhan led the four armies. Xi Kui drove the war chariot, and Yue Zhen served as the right guard. On the *dinghai* day of the fifth month, the Marquis of Jin, leading the allied armies of the feudal lords, fought the Qin forces at Masui. The Qin army was routed, and Cheng Qiang of Qin, along with the officer Ru Fu, were captured. This illustrates that the Earl of Qin broke his oath, that Qin was at fault and Jin was in the right, and that defeat was the consequence.*

chunks.original_text: 义云：李意期乞食于人寰，阴长生受辱于都市，侯道华寓迹于佣保，皇甫獭示疾于丘林，声子佯狂，壶公韬晦，皆卑躬损志，乃翥景冲真也。 广德若不足。 疏：良贾者。 ○义云：《史记》云：孔子与南宫敬叔适周问礼於老子，老子曰：子之所言，其人骨已朽矣，独其言在尔。 吾闻之良贾之深藏若虚，君子之盛德容貌若愚，去子之骄气与多欲，态色与淫志，皆无益于子之身。 吾所以告子者，若是也。 大方无隅。 疏：磨而涅而者。 ○义云：《论语□阳货》篇也。 大器晚成。 义云：备物之用曰器者，《春秋》定九年夏，阳虎归宝玉，夏后民之璜，封父之繁弱大弓。 书之曰得器用也。 凡获器用曰得，得用曰获，故器者备物之用也。 故物或损之而益。 疏：《书》云：满招损者。 ○义云：《尚书□大禹模》之辞也。 强梁者不得其死。 疏：严仙人。 ○义云：蜀郡严遵字君平，常於成都市以卜筮之道潜化於人，人有不正之问，必以阴阳之理制而止之，日阅百钱而闭肆下帘，作《道德经指归》十四卷。 天下之至柔章第四十三 不言之教。

The *Yijue* states: Li Yiqi begged for food among the mortal realm; Yin Changsheng endured humiliation in the marketplace; Hou Daohua concealed his traces as a hired laborer; Huangfu Ta feigned illness in the wooded hills; Shengzi feigned madness; and Master Hu concealed his brilliance. All these exemplars humbled themselves and diminished their aspirations, only thus soaring toward the heights and merging with the True.

**"Vast virtue appears insufficient."**

*Commentary:* The excellent merchant...
*The Yijue* states: The *Records of the Grand Historian* recounts that Confucius, accompanied by Nangong Jingshu, journeyed to Zhou to inquire of Laozi about ritual propriety. Laozi said: "The men of whom you speak are now but dust and bone; only their words remain. I have heard that the excellent merchant conceals his treasures as if his store were empty, and the noble man of abundant virtue bears the countenance of a fool. Shed your arrogance and excess desire, your affected manner and extravagant ambition—none of these benefit your person. What I tell you is just this."

**"The great square has no corners."**

*Commentary:* "Polished yet dyed black..."
*The Yijue* states: This is from the *Analects*, in the "Yang Huo" chapter.

**"Great vessels are slow to complete."**

*The Yijue* states: That which equips things for use is called a "vessel." In the ninth year of Duke Ding of *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Yang Hu returned treasured jades—the *xiahoumin* jade tablet and the great bow *Fengfu’s Luxuriant Might*—recording the event as "obtained vessels." Generally, to obtain vessels is called *de*, and to obtain their use is called *huo*. Thus, a vessel is that which equips things for use.

**"Thus, some things are diminished yet gain."**

*Commentary:* The *Book of Documents* states: "Fullness invites diminishment..."
*The Yijue* states: These are the words from the "Counsels of Great Yu" in the *Book of Documents*.

**"The strong and overbearing do not meet their proper end."**

*Commentary:* The Immortal Yan...
*The Yijue* states: Yan Zun, styled Junping, of Shu Commandery, often practiced divination in the marketplace of Chengdu, subtly transforming people through the Dao. When questioned with improper intent, he invariably restrained and corrected them with the principles of yin and yang. Daily, he earned a hundred coins before closing his shop and lowering the curtain, composing the *Zhigui* (Pointers to the *Dao and Its Virtue*) in fourteen scrolls.

**Chapter Forty-Three: The Softest Under Heaven**
**"The teaching without words."**

chunks.original_text: 疏：九流百氏。 ○义云：九流者，汉书云：道家流者，使人精神专一，动合无形，赡足万物，其为术也，因阴阳之大顺，与时迁徙，应物变化，本清虚以自守，卑弱以自持，此人君南面之术也。 儒家流者，盖出司徒之官，助人君明教化，祖述尧舜，宪章文武，宗师仲尼，以重其言，於道最高，此其所长也，或失精微而僻，又随时抑扬，违离道本，苟以哗众取容，后进僻儒之息。 名家流者，盖出於春宫，名位不同，礼亦异数。 子曰：必也正名乎，此其所长也。 及徼为之，则苟钩鈲析辞而已。 为君者慎器与名，故曰惟名与器，不可以假人。 纵横流者，盖出於行人之官。 子曰：使於四方，不能专对。 又曰：使乎使乎，言当权事制宜，受命不受辞，此其所长也。 邪而为之，财尚诈而弃其信矣。 杂家流者，盖出於议官，合儒墨，兼名法，此其所长也。 荡而为之，则羡无归心矣。 农家流者，盖出於农官，播五谷以足衣足食，洪范八政其一曰食，此其所长也。 鄙者为之，欲使君子并耕矣。 小说家流者，盖出於牌官。 稗，小米也，王者欲知风俗，立牌官采街谭巷议之说。 子曰：虽小道必有可观，政远恐泥，此亦刍荛狂夫之义也。 墨家流者，出於清庙之宇，茅屋采椽，兼受选士，敬者为推也。 阴阳家流者，出於天官五行之说，使人多拘忌也。 兵家流者，出於司马之官，所以威不轨而昭文德，兼弱攻昧，以遏乱略，以靖四国，此其威也。 百氏者，六经正史之外，自为述作，自周以来，立理着书，凡百余人，皆称曰子。 子者男子之通称也，不敢侔於六经，皆目之曰子，为论为记为书，或以姓氏立称，或以因时表号，则有鬻常子、曾子、晏子、孟子、管子、孙卿子、鲁连子、列子、庄子、庚桑子、王孙子、尹文子、公孙尼子、吕氏春秋、邓析音昔子、鬼谷子之例是也。 名与身章第四十四 名与身孰亲。 义云：伯夷死於仁，聂政死於义，尾生死於信，荆轲死於勇，龙逢死於谏，伍员死於忠，介推死於怒，是皆名显身殁，形骨飘零，披面剖心，火焚水溺，齿剑抉眼，自取灭亡。 甚爱必大废，多藏必厚亡。 疏：剑玉贾害，譬诸怀璧，诗礼发冢，只为含珠。 ○义云：剑玉者，《春秋》桓十年虞公之弟虞叔有玉，虞公求之，弗与，既而悔之，曰：周谚有之，匹夫无罪，怀璧之罪，吾焉用此，其以贾害也。 乃献之。 又求其宝剑，叔曰：是无厌也。 无厌，将及我，恐将杀我也。 遂伐虞公，虞公出奔洪池。 诗礼发冢者，《庄子》外篇之辞也。 大成若缺章第四十五 躁胜寒，静胜热。

**Commentary:** The nine schools and the hundred masters.

*The Yijue* states: The "nine schools" are as follows, according to the *Book of Han*: The Daoist school enables one to unify the spirit, act in accord with the formless, and suffice for the myriad things. Its methods follow the great harmony of yin and yang, shift with the times, respond to things with transformation, and are rooted in purity and emptiness for self-preservation, humility and softness for self-sustenance—this is the art of the ruler facing south.

The Confucian school, originating from the office of the Minister of Education, assists the ruler in illuminating moral transformation, tracing its lineage to Yao and Shun, modeling itself on Wen and Wu, and taking Confucius as its master to lend weight to its words. It is the highest in the Dao, and this is its strength. Yet it may lose its subtlety and become biased, or bend with the times, straying from the root of the Dao, merely seeking to please the crowd and accommodate others—such are the flaws of later, perverse Confucians.

The School of Names originates from the Spring Office, where ranks differ and rites vary accordingly. Confucius said: "It is essential to rectify names"—this is its strength. But when taken to excess, it becomes mere hair-splitting and sophistry.

The School of Diplomacy originates from the office of the Messenger. Confucius said: "One sent on a mission to the four quarters cannot be expected to improvise replies," and also: "A messenger! A messenger!"—meaning one must weigh affairs and adapt to circumstances, receiving commands but not the words. This is its strength. Yet when practiced deceitfully, it values cunning and abandons trust.

The Eclectic school originates from the office of the Counselor, blending Confucianism and Mohism, combining the Schools of Names and Laws—this is its strength. But when taken to excess, it becomes aimless and without a guiding principle.

The Agricultural school originates from the office of the Minister of Agriculture, sowing the five grains to ensure ample clothing and food. The *Great Plan* lists eight policies, the first being food—this is its strength. Yet when vulgarized, it seeks to make gentlemen till the soil alongside commoners.

The School of Minor Talks originates from the office of the Recorder of Popular Sayings. "Bai" means small grain; the ruler, wishing to know customs, established this office to gather street gossip and alleyway discussions. Confucius said: "Even in minor ways there is something worth observing, but pursuing them too far may lead to entanglement"—this is also the meaning of "the words of grass-cutters and madmen."

The Mohist school originates from the attendants of the ancestral temple, with thatched roofs and rough-hewn rafters, selecting worthy men and esteeming those who yield. The Yin-Yang school originates from the astronomical office and the theory of the Five Phases, leading people to excessive taboos and restrictions.

The Military school originates from the office of the Minister of War, serving to awe those who defy the law and manifest civil virtue, to annex the weak and attack the benighted, to curb disorder and pacify the four quarters—this is its might.

The "hundred masters" refer to those outside the Six Classics and orthodox histories who established their own doctrines and composed works. Since the Zhou dynasty, over a hundred individuals have set forth principles and written books, all called "Masters." "Master" is a general term for men; not daring to equate themselves with the Six Classics, they are all designated as "Masters," whether in treatises, records, or books. Some are named after their surnames, others by their era or title—examples include Master Yuchang, Master Zeng, Master Yan, Master Meng, Master Guan, Master Xunqing, Master Lulian, Master Lie, Master Zhuang, Master Gengsang, Master Wangsun, Master Yinwen, Master Gongsun Ni, *Master Lü’s Spring and Autumn Annals*, Deng Xi (also called Master Xishi), and Master Guigu.

**Chapter Forty-Four: Name and Life**
**Name and life—which is dearer?**

*The Yijue* states: Boyi died for benevolence, Nie Zheng died for righteousness, Weisheng died for trust, Jing Ke died for courage, Long Feng died for remonstrance, Wu Yun died for loyalty, Jie Zitui died for resentment—all achieved fame but lost their lives, their bones scattered, faces flayed, hearts carved out, burned by fire or drowned in water, eyes gouged by swords. They brought ruin upon themselves.

**Excessive love must lead to great loss; hoarding wealth must lead to heavy ruin.**

**Commentary:** The harm of prizing jade is like holding a jade disk; the tomb-robbing of the refined is only for the pearls within.

*The Yijue* states: As for prizing jade, in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the tenth year of Duke Huan, Yu Gong’s younger brother Yu Shu possessed a jade. Yu Gong demanded it, but Yu Shu refused. Later, Yu Shu regretted it, saying: "There is a Zhou proverb: 'A commoner is blameless, but possessing a jade disk is a crime.' Why do I need this? It will only bring harm." He then presented it. Yu Gong further demanded his precious sword. Yu Shu said: "He is insatiable. If he is insatiable, it will reach me—I fear he will kill me." He then attacked Yu Gong, who fled to Hongchi.

As for the tomb-robbing of the refined, this is a saying from the Outer Chapters of the *Zhuangzi*.

**Chapter Forty-Five: Great Perfection Seems Deficient**
**Restlessness overcomes cold; stillness overcomes heat.**

**Annotation states:** The *Tian Yuan Jing* says: After the Beginning of Summer, the sun travels along the north of the earth, entering the ground shallowly, thus nights are short and days long—this brings heat. After the Beginning of Autumn, the sun travels along the south of the earth, entering the ground deeply, thus nights are long and days short—this brings coolness. The sun’s distance from the pole varies, giving rise to warmth, coolness, cold, and heat. Thus, cold and heat, restlessness and stillness, are the movements of yang qi.

As for the ruler who employs the Dao, governing through non-action brings order: his governance is still, and all things thrive; the state is secure, and the people are at peace. The four frontiers submit in allegiance; the five weapons lie unused. Clarity and emptiness congeal in tranquility; purity and silence abide in harmony. Deceit dares not encroach; violence dares not rage. Beacon fires remain unlit; war drums do not startle. Within the seas, all is serene—this is stillness prevailing.

When his transformative influence reaches its height, songs of praise resound in unison; reverence and deference flourish. The ninefold circuits harmonize; the four gates stand solemn. Ritual is established; music is composed. The worthy are elevated; the capable are employed. Ships and carriages converge in hope at his court; written laws and axle-tracks align with his governance. The eight frontiers gather in submission; the myriad regions hasten in allegiance. Heaven and earth respond in resonance; humans and spirits commune in harmony. All under heaven transforms in radiant accord with the Dao.

Within, there is no scheming through cracks; without, there are no neighboring states watching for openings. They sing of it, savor it, dance to it, and leap in joy—this is the achievement of stillness, governance, and non-action.

If, however, the ruler is restless and reckless, his ministers deceitful and cunning, stirring up arms and flaunting power and favor—mobilizing a million-strong army to ascend the Chanyu’s terrace, banners stretching a thousand *li* to cross the shores of the Pei and Liao—then the old and weak are pressed into labor, women compelled to transport supplies. The four seas seethe; the six directions convulse. When the people are exhausted, households dwindle, lives are uprooted, the wilds lie deserted, and ghosts wail by day—this is the consequence of restlessness prevailing.

chunks.original_text: 前巫后史，卜筮瞽侑，列於左右，无为而守至正也。 三公在朝，三老在学，百辟奉职，修文德以怀远，敷道化以育人，使俗洽和平，家兴礼让，来琛赆於四塞，息征戍於三边倒载干戈，休牛归马，然后乐耕褥粪田畴，多稼如云，余粮栖亩，苟或违此，则怨敌交侵，戎马载驰，甲兵复用，此无道之所为也。 天下有道，却走马以粪。 义曰：古人有言曰：君犹舟也，人犹水也。 人非君不理，舟非水不行。 舟水相须，不可暂失，故理国之本，养人为先。 有道之君，守在四夷，外无兵寇，戈循不用，锋镝不施，却甲为於三边，辟田畴於四野，深耕浅种，家给国肥，食为人天，务之大务也。 《礼记》云：人者，天地之德，阴阳之交，鬼神之会，五行之秀，故圣人作则必以天地为本，阴阳为端，四时为柄，日星为纪，鬼神以为徒，五行以为质，礼义以为器，人情以为田，四灵以为畜，故人情者圣王之田也。 情田无为，几於道矣。 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 义曰：理国不以道，则开拓边土，侵伐戎夷，封域不宁，征役无已，或贪蒟酱起番禺之役，好名马起大宛之师，骨壅穷荒，血涂草莽，营魄流飘於异域，戎车沦滞於远郊，绵岁月以长征，及瓜时而不反，转输莫息，杼轴甚空，人怨国亡，祸非天与，所宜深戒也。 岂若宇内不扰，诸侯咸宾，君民协和，上下相保，使壮士无所施其力，辩士无所衒其词武士无所锐其锋，智士无所申其策，铸剑戟以为犁锄，货佩刀而市耕犊，无为无役，以全永图。 罪莫大於可欲。 义云：《春秋》曰：僖二十年，宋襄公欲合诸侯，鲁大夫臧文仲闻之曰：以欲从人则可，以人从欲鲜济。 言屈己欲从众善也。 明年，宋公为鹿上之盟，宋公子目夷曰：小国争盟，幸而后败。 是年秋，楚人执宋公，遂伐宋，此言以人从欲，乖其道也。 咎莫大於欲得。 义云：《老君悔过经》云：初犯为罪，亦名为过。 过言误也。 犯过一千八十为祸，祸重於罪矣。 犯千二百六十过为咎，咎又重於祸矣。 不出户章第四十七 不为而成。

When shamans stand before and scribes behind, with diviners and blind musicians arrayed to left and right, one governs through non-action and upholds perfect rectitude. The Three Dukes attend court, the Three Elders reside in the academy, and the myriad officials fulfill their duties—cultivating civil virtue to embrace distant lands, spreading the transformative power of the Dao to nurture the people, so that customs become harmonious and peaceful, households flourish in ritual propriety, and tribute flows in from the four frontiers. The three borders see no military campaigns; shields and spears are upturned, warhorses retired to pasture, oxen returned to the plow. Then the people delight in tilling the soil, enriching the fields, and the harvests grow thick as clouds, with surplus grain spilling over the furrows. Should one deviate from this path, however, resentful enemies will invade in concert, warhorses gallop unchecked, and armor and weapons are once more put to use—such are the works of a realm without the Dao.

When all under heaven possesses the Dao, warhorses are sent back to fertilize the fields.

**Annotation states:** The ancients said: "The ruler is like a boat; the people are like water. Without the ruler, the people cannot be governed; without water, the boat cannot move. Boat and water depend on each other and cannot be separated even for a moment. Thus, the foundation of governing a state lies first in nurturing the people." When a ruler abides by the Dao, his guardianship extends to the four barbarian tribes; beyond his borders, there are no military incursions, halberds lie unused, and blades and arrowheads remain sheathed. Armor is set aside at the three borders, and fields are opened across the four wildernesses. Deep plowing and shallow sowing ensure that households are well-provided and the state grows prosperous. Food is the people’s heaven—its cultivation is the greatest of all tasks. As the *Record of Rites* says: "Man is the virtue of heaven and earth, the convergence of yin and yang, the meeting of ghosts and spirits, the finest essence of the five phases. Thus, when the sage establishes norms, he must take heaven and earth as his foundation, yin and yang as his starting point, the four seasons as his handle, the sun and stars as his markers, ghosts and spirits as his companions, the five phases as his substance, ritual propriety as his vessel, human sentiment as his field, and the four sacred creatures as his livestock. Therefore, human sentiment is the sage-king’s field. When the field of sentiment is cultivated through non-action, it approaches the Dao."

When all under heaven lacks the Dao, warhorses breed in the suburbs.

**Annotation states:** If a state is governed without the Dao, its rulers will expand borders and invade barbarian lands, leaving frontiers restless and conscription unending. Some, coveting spices, launch campaigns against distant Fan Yu; others, desiring fine horses, raise armies against Da Yuan. Bones pile in the barren wilds, blood soaks the grassy marshes, souls drift and scatter in foreign lands, and war chariots sink into the distant suburbs. Years stretch on in endless campaigns, and soldiers do not return even when the melons ripen. Transport never ceases, and the looms stand empty. The people resent, the state perishes—such calamities are not heaven-sent but arise from what should be deeply guarded against. How much better to keep the realm undisturbed, so that the feudal lords all submit, ruler and people harmonize, and superiors and inferiors protect one another. Then the strong have no outlet for their strength, the eloquent no stage for their words, warriors no edge for their blades, and the wise no chance to deploy their strategies. Swords and halberds are recast into plows and hoes; daggers are traded in the market for oxen to till the fields. Without action or conscription, the people preserve their lives and secure their futures.

No crime is greater than indulging desire.

**Annotation states:** The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records: "In the twentieth year of Duke Xi, Duke Xiang of Song sought to unite the feudal lords. Zang Wenzhong, a minister of Lu, heard of this and said: 'To follow others in fulfilling one’s desires is acceptable, but to make others follow one’s desires rarely succeeds.' This means bending one’s own desires to align with the greater good. The following year, the Duke of Song convened the Alliance at Lu Shang. Gongzi Mu Yi of Song remarked: 'When small states vie for leadership in alliances, they are fortunate to escape defeat.' That autumn, the men of Chu seized the Duke of Song and attacked his state—this illustrates how making others follow one’s desires strays from the Dao."

No misfortune is greater than covetousness.

**Annotation states:** The *Scripture of Laozi’s Repentance* states: "The first transgression is called a sin, also known as a fault. *Guo* (fault) means error. Committing 1,080 faults leads to calamity, and calamity is weightier than sin. Committing 1,260 faults leads to *jiu* (misfortune), and misfortune is weightier still than calamity."

chunks.original_text: 疏：凝神端扆。 ○义云：凝，静也。 端，庄肃也。 扆，龙屏也，谓倚也，形若屏风，画为斧文，於明堂之中牖间而设之。 昔周公辅成王於明堂以朝诸侯，负斧扆南面而立，以正君臣之位。 为学日益章第四十八 为学日益。 义云：学者，觉也，悟也，言以先王之道开导情性，使觉悟也。 幼则昏迷而不悟，未可以学，长则捍格而难入，不可以教。 学有三时，一就人身中为时者，十三岁之后，可以习业也，故《学记》云：发然而后禁，则捍格而不胜，时过而后学，则勤苦而难成。 二就年中为时者，《内则》云：人之养子，六年教之，数一到十，十至百千万也，与方名，东西南北也。 七年男女不同席，不共食。 八年出入门户，及即席饮食，必后於长者，教之让也。 九年教之数日，朔望与 甲乙到壬癸，六甲也。 十年出就外傅，居宿於外，学书计。 十有三年，学舞勺诵诗，背文而读曰诵也。 十五年成童舞象，学射御。 先舞钥，钥似笛，执而文舞也。 后舞象，武舞也。 二十四而冠，始学礼。 三十有室，理男事，学无方。 四十而仕，出谋发虑。 五十服冠政是也。 三就日中为时者，言随时节气，受业易入。 《王制》曰：春夏习诗雅言，春夏是阳，阳体清，诗乐是声，声以轻清故也。 秋冬习书礼，秋冬是阴，阴体重，书礼是事，事以重浊故也。 以轻清之时，习轻清之业，以重浊之时，习重浊之事，故其气相感，皆易入也。 出生人死章第五十 动之死地十有三。 义曰：人之禀生，有三业十恶。 三业者，一身，二心，三口业也。 十恶者，身业有三恶，一杀生，二偷盗，三邪淫。 心业亦有三恶，一贪欲，二嗔怒，三愚痴。 口业有四，一两舌，二恶口，一二妄言，四绮语。 此三业十恶，合为十有三矣。 制则生，纵则死矣，此十恶中各有四缘，皆为烦恼根。 何者？ 杀生罪中有四种缘，一实是众生，二起众生想，三有欲杀心，四令断他命。 偷盗罪中亦有四缘，一实是他物，二起他物想，三有欲盗心，四使移本处。 邪淫罪中亦有四缘，一实是邪境，二起邪境想，三发邪淫心，四身受染乐事。 两舌罪中亦有四缘，一是所闻人，二起前人想，三起离间情，四发分构语。 恶口罪中亦有四缘，一是所骂人，二起前人想，三起恶骂心，四发恶骂语。 妄言罪中亦有四缘，一是所欺人，二起前人想，三有欺妄心，四成虚违说。 绮语罪中亦有四缘，一是所诈人，二起前人想，三发绮语心，四吐非义语。 凡此十恶业，计五十三条。 陆行不遇兕虎。

**Chapter Forty-Eight: Daily Advancement in Learning**
Daily advancement in learning.
**Annotation states:** *Learning* means awakening and enlightenment, referring to guiding one’s nature and emotions with the Way of the former kings to achieve understanding. In youth, one is benighted and unenlightened, unfit for learning; in maturity, one becomes obstinate and resistant, difficult to instruct. There are three timelinesses in learning:

First, the timeliness within the human body: after the age of thirteen, one may begin to study, as the *Record of Learning* states: "If restraint is imposed only after impulses arise, resistance will prevail; if learning begins only after the proper time has passed, it will be arduous and difficult to succeed."

Second, the timeliness within the year: the *Nei Ze* states: "In raising a child, at six years, teach them to count from one to ten, then to a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand, and to recognize directions—east, west, south, and north. At seven, boys and girls do not share the same mat nor eat together. At eight, they learn to enter and exit doors and take their seats at meals, always deferring to elders—this teaches them deference. At nine, they are taught the days of the month, the new and full moons, and the heavenly stems from *jia* to *gui*, as well as the six *jia* days. At ten, they go to external tutors, reside outside the home, and study writing and arithmetic. At thirteen, they learn the *Shao* dance and recite the *Odes*—recitation means reading aloud from memory. At fifteen, as youths, they learn the *Xiang* dance, archery, and charioteering. First, they perform the *Yue* dance, where the *yue* resembles a flute, held while performing the civil dance; later, they perform the *Xiang* dance, the martial dance. At twenty-four, they undergo the capping ceremony and begin to study ritual. At thirty, they marry, manage affairs of men, and study without fixed method. At forty, they enter office, offering counsel and devising plans. At fifty, they assume governance—this is the sequence."

Third, the timeliness within the day: learning is more readily absorbed when aligned with the seasons and qi. The *Royal Regulations* states: "In spring and summer, study the *Odes* and refined speech, for spring and summer are yang, and yang is light and clear—poetry and music are sounds, and sounds are naturally light and clear. In autumn and winter, study writing and ritual, for autumn and winter are yin, and yin is heavy and turbid—writing and ritual are affairs, and affairs are naturally heavy and turbid. Practicing light and clear studies in light and clear seasons, and heavy and turbid studies in heavy and turbid seasons, ensures that their qi resonate and are easily absorbed."

**Chapter Fifty: Birth and Death in the World of Humans**
Thirteen paths lead to the realm of death.
**Annotation states:** In receiving life, humans possess three karmic actions and ten evils. The three karmic actions are: first, bodily action; second, mental action; and third, verbal action. The ten evils are: bodily action has three evils—killing living beings, theft, and sexual misconduct. Mental action also has three evils—greed, anger, and delusion. Verbal action has four—divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, and frivolous speech. These three karmic actions and ten evils together make thirteen.

Restraint leads to life; indulgence leads to death. Each of these ten evils has four conditions, all rooted in afflictions. What are they?

For the sin of killing: four conditions—first, the being is truly alive; second, one conceives the thought that it is a living being; third, one harbors the intention to kill; fourth, one causes its life to end.

For the sin of theft: four conditions—first, the object truly belongs to another; second, one conceives the thought that it is another’s property; third, one harbors the intention to steal; fourth, one moves it from its original place.

For the sin of sexual misconduct: four conditions—first, the object is truly an improper partner; second, one conceives the thought that it is an improper partner; third, one generates the intention for sexual misconduct; fourth, the body experiences defiled pleasure.

For the sin of divisive speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who has been heard; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention to sow discord; fourth, one utters speech that creates division.

For the sin of harsh speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who is cursed; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention to curse; fourth, one utters abusive language.

For the sin of false speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who is deceived; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention to deceive; fourth, one makes statements that are untrue.

For the sin of frivolous speech: four conditions—first, the person is truly one who is deceived; second, one conceives the thought of that person; third, one generates the intention for frivolous speech; fourth, one utters words that are improper.

In total, these ten evil actions comprise fifty-three conditions.

Traveling by land, one does not encounter rhinoceroses or tigers.

chunks.original_text: 疏：忧悔吝者，《易□系辞》也。 使我介然章第五十三 带利剑。 义云：武备者，《春秋》定十年夏，与齐景公会于夹谷，孔子摄行相事，曰：臣闻有文事者，必有武备，有武备者，必有文备。 诸侯出疆，必具官从，请具左右司马。 定公从之。 会所为坛位，土阶三等，以遇礼相见，揖让而登，献酬已毕，齐使莱人以兵鼓噪劫定公，孔子历阶而进，不尽一等，以公退，曰：士兵之。 吾两君为好，而裔夷之俘敢以兵乱之，非齐君所以命诸侯也。 裔不谋夏，夷不乱华，俘不干盟，兵不逼好，於神为不祥，於德於#3为愆义，於人为失礼，君必不然。 齐侯心怍，麾而避之。 有顷，齐侯奏宫中之乐，倡优侏儒戏於公前，孔子趋进，历阶而上，不尽一等，曰：匹夫而荧侮诸侯者，罪应诛，请有司速加法焉。 於是斩侏儒手足异处。 齐侯惧，有惭色。 既盟诸侯，归责其群臣曰：鲁以君子之道辅其君，而子独以夷狄之道教寡人，使寡人得罪於鲁君，乃归所侵鲁郓、讙、龟阴之田，此文事武备也。 善建者不拔章第五十四 善建者不拔。 疏：使仪刑作孚。 ○义云：《诗□大雅》曰：仪刑文王，万邦作孚。 孚，信也。 文王以道垂化，万邦归信也。 修之家。 疏：《易》曰：积善之家。 ○义云：《易》坤卦文言也。 修之天下。 义云：天子味道耽玄，敬天顺地，凝心玄默，端己无为，书轨大同，梯航入贡，四夷款附，万国来王，道无不被，其德周普矣。 庙堂者，天#4子政事之所也。 德施普者，《易》乾卦象曰：见龙在田，德施普也。 以天下观天下。 义云：君不修则桀纣是也。

**Chapter Fifty-Three: Let Me Be Firmly Resolved**
Girded with a sword of profit.

**Annotation:** On military preparedness—In the summer of the tenth year of Duke Ding’s reign, as recorded in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Confucius met with Duke Jing of Qi at Jiagu while acting as steward. He said: "Your servant has heard that where there are civil affairs, there must be military preparedness; where there is military preparedness, there must be civil preparedness. When the feudal lords cross borders, they must bring their officials in attendance. I request that you prepare your left and right marshals." Duke Ding consented. At the meeting site, an altar was raised with three tiers of earthen steps, and they exchanged courtesies according to ritual, ascending with bows. After the exchange of toasts, the Qi envoys sent men of Lai, armed and drumming wildly, to seize Duke Ding. Confucius ascended the steps in haste, stopping one tier short of the top, and withdrew the Duke, saying: "Send forth the soldiers! Our two lords meet in friendship, yet these barbarian captives dare disrupt it with arms—this is not how the Lord of Qi commands the feudal lords. Barbarians do not scheme against the Central States; Yi tribes do not disturb Hua; captives do not violate covenants; arms do not threaten amity. Before the gods, this is inauspicious; in virtue, it is a breach of righteousness; among men, it is a breach of propriety. My lord would surely not permit this." The Marquis of Qi, conscience-stricken, waved them away. After a while, the Marquis of Qi presented palace musicians, and actors and dwarves performed before the Duke. Confucius strode forward, ascended the steps, stopping one tier short, and said: "Commoners who deceive and insult the feudal lords deserve execution. Let the officials swiftly apply the law." Thereupon, the dwarves were slain, their limbs severed. The Marquis of Qi, terrified, showed shame. After the covenant with the feudal lords, he reproached his ministers, saying: "Lu aids its lord with the Way of the noble man, while you alone instruct me in the ways of barbarians, causing me to offend the Lord of Lu." He then returned the seized lands of Yun, Huan, and Guiyin to Lu—this is civil affairs and military preparedness.

**Chapter Fifty-Four: What Is Well Established Cannot Be Uprooted**
What is well established cannot be uprooted.

**Commentary:** Let models of conduct inspire trust.

**Annotation:** The *Book of Songs* in the *Greater Odes* states: "Take King Wen as your model, and the myriad states will place their trust in you." *Fu* means "trust." King Wen extended the Dao in his teachings, and the myriad states submitted in faith.

Cultivate it in your household.

**Commentary:** The *Book of Changes* says: "The household that accumulates goodness..."

**Annotation:** This is from the *Wenyan* commentary on the *Kun* hexagram.

Cultivate it throughout the world.

**Annotation:** When the Son of Heaven savors the Dao and delights in the profound, reveres Heaven and follows Earth, concentrates his mind in mysterious stillness, rectifies himself through non-action, unifies the standards of writing, and accepts tribute from distant lands, the Four Yi submit in sincerity, and the myriad states come to pay homage. The Dao extends without exception, and his virtue is universally pervasive. The ancestral temple is where the Son of Heaven conducts the affairs of state.

When virtue is universally bestowed—The *Xiang* commentary on the *Qian* hexagram in the *Book of Changes* states: "The dragon appears in the field; virtue is universally bestowed."

Observe the world through the world.

**Annotation:** If the ruler does not cultivate it, he becomes like Jie or Zhou.

chunks.original_text: 将立州吁，乃早定之。 若犹未也，阶之为祸。 夫宠而不骄，骄而能降，降而不憾，憾而能眕者，鲜矣。 且夫贱妨贵，少凌长，远间亲，新间旧，小加大，淫破义，所谓六逆也。 君义臣行，父慈子孝，兄爱弟敬，所谓六顺也。 去顺效逆，所以速祸也。 君人者，将祸是务去，而速之，无乃不可乎。 弗听。 石碏之子厚与州吁游，禁之不可。 桓公立，碏乃老。 二月戊申，州吁弒桓公而自立。 将修先君之怨於郑，而求宠於诸侯，以和其民，使来告於宋曰：君若伐郑以除君害，君为主，弊邑以赋与陈、蔡从，则卫国之愿也。 宋人许之。 於是陈、蔡将睦於卫，故宋与陈、蔡卫伐郑，围其东门，五日而还。 宋公乞师於鲁，鲁辞之。 隐公问於众仲曰：州吁其成乎？ 对曰：臣闻以德和民，不闻以乱理乱。 理乱犹理丝而棼之也，夫州吁弒其君，而虐用其民，不务令德，而欲以乱成，必不免也。 州吁未能和其民，厚问定君於石子，石子曰：王觐为可。 曰：何以得觐？ 曰陈桓公方有宠於王，陈卫方睦，若朝陈使请，必可得也。 厚从州吁如陈，石碏使告于陈曰：卫国褊小，老夫耄矣，无能为也。 此二人者，实弒寡君，敢即图之。 陈人执之而请莅於卫。 九月，卫人使右宰丑#1吁于濮，石碏使其宰孺乃侯切羊肩杀石厚于陈。 君子曰：石碏，纯臣也，恶州吁而厚预焉，大义灭亲，其是之谓乎。 所谓子从杀君之贼，国之大逆，不可不除，故云大义灭亲。 明小义则兼爱其子也。 人多伎巧。

Should the intent to enthrone Zhouxu be settled early, then let it be settled early. If it remains unresolved, it will become the very step that invites calamity. Now, those who are favored yet not arrogant, arrogant yet able to yield, yielding yet without resentment, resentful yet able to restrain themselves—such men are rare indeed. Moreover, the lowly encroaching upon the noble, the young overbearing the elder, the distant estranging the near, the new supplanting the old, the lesser dominating the greater, and excess undermining righteousness—these are the six forms of rebellion. The lord acting with propriety and the minister with loyalty, the father with kindness and the son with filial piety, the elder brother with affection and the younger with respect—these are the six forms of harmony. To abandon harmony and emulate rebellion is to hasten disaster. As one who rules over men, you must strive to eliminate calamity, yet you would hasten it—is this not unacceptable?

The lord did not heed his counsel. Shi Que’s son, Shi Hou, befriended Zhouxu and could not be dissuaded. When Duke Huan ascended the throne, Shi Que retired. On the *wushen* day of the second month, Zhouxu murdered Duke Huan and usurped the rulership. Seeking to avenge the grievances of his late lord against Zheng and to curry favor with the feudal lords to pacify his people, he dispatched envoys to Song, saying: "If you, my lord, would lead an expedition against Zheng to remove its threat to you, and take command, our humble state will follow with Chen and Cai in support—this is the wish of the state of Wei." The lord of Song agreed. Thereupon, Chen and Cai, desiring to align with Wei, joined Song, Chen, Cai, and Wei in attacking Zheng, besieging its eastern gate for five days before withdrawing.

The Duke of Song sought reinforcements from Lu, but Lu declined. Duke Yin of Lu inquired of Zhongzhong: "Will Zhouxu succeed?" He replied: "I have heard that one harmonizes the people through virtue, not through disorder to govern disorder. Governing disorder is like sorting tangled silk—only to entangle it further. Zhouxu murdered his lord and cruelly exploited his people. He does not cultivate virtuous governance but seeks to succeed through chaos. He will not escape ruin."

Zhouxu, unable to pacify his people, asked Shi Hou how to secure his rule. Shi Hou consulted Shi Que, who said: "An audience with the king would suffice." Hou asked: "How may one obtain such an audience?" Shi Que replied: "Duke Huan of Chen currently enjoys the king’s favor, and Chen and Wei are on good terms. If you go to Chen and request an introduction, it will surely be granted." Shi Hou accompanied Zhouxu to Chen, where Shi Que sent word: "Wei is a small and narrow state, and I, an old man, am feeble and incapable. These two men murdered my lord. I humbly urge you to take action against them." The men of Chen arrested them and sought Wei’s consent to execute them. In the ninth month, the people of Wei dispatched Youzai Chou to execute Zhouxu at Pu. Shi Que instructed his steward, Ru Naihou, to kill Shi Hou in Chen.

The gentleman remarks: "Shi Que was a minister of pure loyalty. Though he despised Zhouxu, his own son was complicit. He upheld the great principle of severing kinship for righteousness—this is what is meant by such a saying. For a son to follow a regicidal traitor is the gravest treason against the state, which cannot be left unpunished. Thus, it is called 'severing kinship for righteousness.' If lesser principles were observed, one would love one’s son without distinction. Yet men often resort to cunning and deceit."

chunks.original_text: 义云：《春秋》丹桓宫之楹，刻桓宫之桷角，椽也，书而讥之，臧文仲山节藻税也。 法令滋彰。 义云：《礼运》曰：大道既隐，天下为家，城郭沟池以为固，礼义以为理，故谋用是作，而兵由此起。 法令滋彰，盗贼多有，《春秋》曰：夏有乱政而作禹刑，殷有乱政而有汤刑，周有乱政而作九刑，三辟之具，皆叔世也。 民是以乱，免而无耻也。 其政闷闷章第五十八 祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏。 义云：齐有仲孙之难而桓公兴，遂霸其国。 晋有里克之难而文公作，而把诸侯，是二国因祸而昌也。 卫方宁静，狄人灭之，邢方晏安，卫人灭之，是二国无祸而丧也，故伏藏因倚，莫知其极。 故《春秋》云：有祸而启其疆土，无祸而丧其守宇，不可知也。 其无正邪？ 义云：侧身修德，雊雉不足以贻灾。 坦虑忘怀，失马未必以为祸。 悔吝无准，召之由人焉。 治人事天章第五十九 治人事天。 疏：粢盛丰备。 ○义云：《春秋》桓公六年，楚武王侵随，使其大夫薳音苇章求成焉，军於随之瑕地以待之。 随人使少师董成，斗伯比言於楚子曰：吾不得志於汉东也，我则使然。 我张五三二军而被吾甲兵，以武临之，彼则惧矣。 而和协以谋我，故难问也。 汉东之国，以随为大，随张必弃小国，小国离，楚之利也。 少师侈，请赢师以张之。 熊率音律且子余切比曰：随贤臣季良在，何益？ 斗伯比曰：以为后图。 季良谏，不过一见从，少师得其君心，行少师之计。 王毁军而纳少师，少师归请追楚师。 随侯将许之，季良止之曰：天方授楚，楚之赢师，诱我也。 君何急焉。 臣闻小之能敌大也，小道大淫，所谓道者，忠於民而信於神。 上思利民，忠也。 祝史正词，信也。 今民馁而君逞欲，祝史矫举以祭，臣不知其可也。 随侯曰：吾牲牷肥腯音突，粢盛丰备，何则不信？ 对曰：夫民，神之主也。 是以圣王先成民而后致力於神，故奉牲以告曰：博硕肥腯，谓民力之普存也，谓其畜之硕大蕃滋也，谓其不疾瘀音族蠡力果切也，谓其备物咸有也。 奉粢盛而告曰：洁粢丰盛，谓其三时不害，而民和年丰也，奉酒醴以告曰：嘉栗旨酒，谓其上下皆有嘉德，而无违心。 所谓馨香无谗慝也。 务其三时，修其五教，亲其九族，以致其里祀，於是乎民和而神降之福，故动则有成。 今民各有心而鬼神乏主，君虽独丰，其何福之有？ 君姑修政而亲兄弟之国，庶免於难。 随侯惧而修政，楚不敢伐矣。 三时者，春耕夏种秋收，农之三时也。 夫惟啬。 注：何以聚人曰财。 ○义云：《易□下系》云：天地之大德曰生，圣人之大宝曰位，何以守位？ 曰仁。 何以聚人，曰财。 财所以资生者也。 可以有国。 疏：《易》曰：王假有庙有家是也。 ○义云：有国者，车轨所及，书文所同，人服其德，远怀其化，可以谓之有国矣。 或以武威所制，诡道所临，苟有其邦，人所未服，或承平统历，嗣位守国，厥德有愆，恩化不浃者，皆非谓其国矣。 王假有庙有家者，《易》萃卦云：王假有庙，致孝享也。 假，聚也。 王以聚人，至於有庙，有庙乃以能致其孝享，故曰利见大人。 聚以正也，观其所聚，则天地万物之情可见矣。 天下崩离，则民怨，虽有享祀，与无庙同。 王至大聚之时，孝德乃洽，始可谓之有庙矣。

Virtue states: *The Spring and Autumn Annals* records the painting of pillars in Duke Huan’s palace and the carving of the corners of its rafters—these are the beams—and criticizes them, just as it censures Zang Wenzhong’s "mountain-shaped capitals and water-plant decorations."

Laws and decrees proliferate.
Virtue states: *The Evolution of Rites* says: "When the Great Dao vanished, the world became a possession of households. Walls and moats were made for defense, and ritual and righteousness were used to govern. Thus, schemes arose, and warfare began." Laws and decrees proliferate, and bandits and thieves abound. *The Spring and Autumn Annals* says: "In Xia, disorderly governance led to the Penal Code of Yu; in Yin, to the Penal Code of Tang; in Zhou, to the Nine Punishments—all instruments of penal law belong to degenerate eras." The people are thus in chaos, escaping punishment without shame.

**Chapter 58: Governance in Obscurity**
Disaster leans upon fortune, and fortune hides within disaster.
Virtue states: Qi faced the crisis of Zhongsun and Duke Huan rose to power, ultimately dominating his state. Jin endured the turmoil of Li Ke and Duke Wen emerged, commanding the feudal lords—these two states flourished through disaster. When Wei was at peace, the Di destroyed it; when Xing was secure, Wei annihilated it—these two states perished without disaster. Thus, concealment and dependence have no end. *The Spring and Autumn Annals* says: "Some expand their territory through misfortune, while others lose their domains without calamity—it is unfathomable. Is there no principle to this?"

Virtue states: "One who cultivates virtue by rectifying conduct will not suffer even from the omen of a pheasant’s call. One who is at ease and free from care may lose a horse without considering it a disaster. Regret and misfortune have no fixed pattern—they are summoned by one’s own actions."

**Chapter 59: Governing People and Serving Heaven**
Governing people and serving Heaven.
*Subcommentary*: Abundant sacrificial grains.
Virtue states: In the sixth year of Duke Huan’s reign, *The Spring and Autumn Annals* records that King Wu of Chu invaded Sui. He sent his minister, Wei Zhang, to seek peace, stationing his army at Xia in Sui to await a response. The people of Sui sent Shaoshi to negotiate terms. Dou Bobi said to the King of Chu: "Our lack of success east of the Han is our own doing. We deployed our armies in five-three-two formations, clad in armor, and intimidated them with force—they were terrified. Yet they coordinated to scheme against us, making our task difficult. Among the states east of the Han, Sui is the largest. If Sui expands, it will abandon the smaller states, and their alienation will benefit Chu." Shaoshi was arrogant, so Dou Bobi proposed: "Let us feign weakness to embolden him." Xiong Lübi said: "Sui has the worthy minister Ji Liang—what use is this?" Dou Bobi replied: "For future planning." Ji Liang advised against it, but his counsel was heeded only once. Shaoshi had the ruler’s favor and carried out his own plan. The king disbanded the army to receive Shaoshi. Upon returning, Shaoshi urged the pursuit of Chu’s forces. The Marquis of Sui was about to agree when Ji Liang stopped him: "Heaven is granting favor to Chu. Their feigned weakness is a lure. Why rush?" He continued: "A small state can resist a large one when the small follows the Dao and the large is excessive. The Dao lies in loyalty to the people and trust in the spirits. Loyalty means prioritizing the people’s welfare; trust means the invocators and scribes speaking truthfully. Now the people hunger while the ruler indulges, and the invocators falsify offerings in sacrifice—I do not see how this can succeed." The Marquis of Sui said: "Our sacrificial animals are flawless and fat, our grains abundant—how can we lack trust?" Ji Liang replied: "The people are the masters of the spirits. Thus, sagely kings first ensured the people’s well-being before serving the spirits. When presenting sacrificial animals, they declared: 'Plump and fat,' signifying the people’s universal prosperity, the thriving and abundance of their livestock, their freedom from disease, and the completeness of their possessions. When offering grains, they declared: 'Pure and abundant,' signifying the three seasons passed without harm, the people’s harmony, and a bountiful harvest. When presenting sweet wine, they declared: 'Fine and excellent,' signifying that superiors and inferiors alike possessed virtuous conduct without deceit. This is what is meant by 'fragrant offerings free from slander.' They devoted themselves to the three seasons, cultivated the five teachings, and fostered kinship among the nine clans to perform their village sacrifices. Thus, the people were harmonious, and the spirits bestowed blessings, ensuring success in all undertakings. Now the people have divergent hearts, and the ghosts and spirits lack a master. Though you alone prosper, what blessing can there be? First rectify governance and strengthen ties with brotherly states—perhaps then you may avoid disaster." The Marquis of Sui, alarmed, reformed his governance, and Chu dared not attack.

The three seasons are spring plowing, summer planting, and autumn harvest—the three seasons of agriculture.

**Thrift**
*Annotation*: What gathers people is called wealth.
Virtue states: The *Appended Judgments* of the *Book of Changes* says: "The greatest virtue of Heaven and Earth is life; the greatest treasure of the sage is position. How does one preserve position? Through benevolence. How does one gather people? Through wealth. Wealth is what sustains life." Thus, one can possess a state.

*Subcommentary*: The *Book of Changes* says: "The king reaches the temple and the household"—this is the meaning.
Virtue states: One who possesses a state governs where chariot tracks extend, where written script is shared, where people submit to his virtue and distant lands cherish his transformation—only then can it be called possessing a state. Some rule through military might or deceptive tactics, merely holding territory without the people’s submission. Others inherit a peaceful reign but, due to moral failings and insufficient virtue, do not deeply permeate the people with benevolence—these cannot be said to truly possess a state.

"The king reaches the temple and the household" refers to the *Cui* hexagram of the *Book of Changes*: "The king reaches the temple, offering filial piety." *Jia* means "to gather." The king gathers the people to the temple, and through the temple, he expresses filial devotion—thus it says, "It is beneficial to see the great person." Gathering is for rectification; observing what is gathered reveals the nature of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. When the world is fractured and divided, the people resent, and even with sacrifices, it is as if there were no temple. Only when the king achieves great unity and filial virtue prevails can it be called possessing a temple.

chunks.original_text: 王假有家者，《易》家人卦九五辞云：王假有家，勿恤。 象曰：王假有家，交相爱也。 王能有家道，在下莫不化之，天下既化，六亲和睦，故曰交相爱也。 涣卦亦有王假有庙，其义同也。 是谓深根固蒂，长生久视之道。 ○义云：人君以道德养生灵，以俭啬理天下，丰财则国富，积德则祚隆，远近归心，华戎率服。 又能母养万物，子爱群生，根深则祚历无疆，蒂固则子孙延永，长生久视，奕叶重光。 治大国章第六十 非其鬼不神，其神不伤民。 疏：《春秋》曰：其气焰以取之。 ○义云：《春秋》庄十四年夏，郑厉公自栎侵郑，及大陵，获大夫傅瑕。 瑕曰：苟合我，我请纳君。 与之盟而赦之。 六月甲子，傅瑕杀郑子仪及其二子而纳厉公。 初，郑有祆焉，内蛇与外蛇斗南门之中，内蛇死。 六年而厉公入。 公闻之，问於申繻曰：犹有祆乎？ 对曰：人之所忌，其气焰以取之。 言若火焰，焰未成而进退之时，以喻人心不坚正也。 妖由人兴，人无衅焉，妖不自作。 人弃常则妖兴，故有妖。 厉公入遂杀傅瑕，使谓原繁曰：傅瑕贰，周有常刑，既伏其罪。 纳我而无二心者，吾皆许之上大夫之事。 吾愿与伯父图之。 且寡人出，伯父无里言，入，又不念寡人，社稷有主而外其心，寡人憾焉。 对曰：先君桓公命我宗人典司宗佑石，庙主也，社稷有主而外其心，其何贰如之？ 苟主社稷，国内之民，其谁不为臣？ 臣无二心，天之制也。 子仪在位十四年矣，而谋召君者，庸非二乎？ 庄公之子，犹有八人，若皆 有官爵，行路劝贰，而可以济事，君其若之何？ 臣闻命矣，乃缢而死。 夫两不相伤，故德交归焉。 疏：人为神主。 ○义云：《春秋》僖十九年，宋桓公使邾文公用鄫音缯子於次睢之社，司马子鱼曰：古者六畜不相为用，小事不用大牲，而况敢用人乎？ 祭祀所以为人也，夫人，神之主也，用人，其谁享之？ 齐桓公存三亡国者，以属诸侯，义士犹曰薄德，今君一会而虐二国之君，言执滕子、用鄫子也。 又用诸淫昏之鬼，将以求霸，不亦难乎？ 得死为幸，恐其亡国也。 子鱼，宋公子目夷也。 睢水自汴入泗，而有祆神，东夷杀人以祭之焉。 六畜不相为用者，如祭马祖不可用马，况用人乎。 今圣人以道育之，鬼神交福，两不相害，可谓玄德乎。 大国者下流章第六十一 义云：《春秋》昭三十年，郑游吉对晋大夫士景伯曰：小国事大，在恭其时命。 大国字小，在恤其所无，先王之制也。 取备而已，所以交其好也。 此固大国切於用谦，不在乎以大制小也。 故大国以下小国，则取小国。 义云：《春秋》襄十四年，大国能安抚小国，如晋为盟主，而卫国逐其君而立剽，晋欲讨其罪，晋侯问故於中行献子，偃对曰：不如因而定之，伐之未必得志，而勤诸侯。 史佚有言曰：因重而抚之。 仲虺有言曰：亡者抚之，乱者取之，推亡固存，国之道也。 君其定卫，以待时乎。 冬，会于戚，以谋卫。 此所谓大国之抚小国也。 又大国之聚小国者，谓群方朝会，无代无之，故夏启有钧台之享，在河南也。 商汤有景亳之命，在偃师也。 周武有孟津之誓，成王有岐阳之搜，康王有酆官之朝，在鄂杜也。 穆王有涂山之会，在寿春也。 齐桓有邵陵之师，晋文有践土之盟，皆以大国恤下，小国事上，各得其所也。

"The king reaches the household" refers to the *Jiaren* hexagram of the *Book of Changes*, where the ninth line of the fifth place states: "The king reaches the household—do not worry." The *Xiang* commentary says: "The king reaches the household—mutual love prevails." When the king embodies the Dao of the household, none below fail to be transformed by it. Once the world is transformed, the six relations live in harmony, hence it is called "mutual love." The *Huan* hexagram also speaks of "the king reaches the temple," its meaning being the same. This is the Dao of deep roots and firm stems, the Way of long life and enduring vision.

The *Yi* commentary states: When the ruler nurtures the people with virtue and power, governs the world with frugality, and amasses wealth, the state prospers. When virtue accumulates, the ancestral line flourishes. When near and far submit in heart, and the Hua and Rong alike yield in obedience, and when he can mother and nourish the myriad things while cherishing all living beings as children, then deep roots ensure an unbounded ancestral line, and firm stems guarantee the eternal extension of descendants. This is long life and enduring vision, the radiance of successive generations.

**Chapter Sixty: Governing a Great State**
"Only its own ghosts are efficacious; only its efficacious spirits do not harm the people."

The *Shu* commentary says: *The Spring and Autumn Annals* states, "Its *qi* flames forth to claim it."

The *Yi* commentary says: In the fourteenth year of Duke Zhuang’s reign in *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, Lord Li of Zheng, having fled to Li, invaded Zheng and reached Daling, where he captured the grandee Fu Xia. Fu Xia said, "If you agree to my terms, I will request to restore you to the throne." They swore an alliance, and he was pardoned. On the *jiazi* day of the sixth month, Fu Xia killed Prince Yi of Zheng and his two sons, restoring Lord Li. Earlier, Zheng had experienced an omen: an inner snake and an outer snake fought in the southern gate, and the inner snake died. Six years later, Lord Li reentered the state. The Duke, having heard of this, asked Shen Ru, "Are there still omens?" Shen Ru replied, "What people fear, its *qi* flames forth to claim. This is like fire: when the flame is not yet formed, it is the moment of advance and retreat—an analogy for the human heart not being firm and upright. Portents arise from human actions; without human transgression, portents do not arise on their own. When people abandon constancy, portents arise—hence the omen." After reentering, Lord Li killed Fu Xia and sent word to Yuan Fan, saying, "Fu Xia was disloyal. Zhou has fixed punishments, and he has already paid for his crime. Those who restored me without a divided heart, I will grant the rank of grandee. I wish to discuss this with you, uncle." He continued, "When I went into exile, you offered no counsel; upon my return, you did not think of me. Though the altars of the state had a lord, your heart was elsewhere—I hold this against you." Yuan Fan replied, "Our late lord, Duke Huan, commanded me, the lineage steward, to oversee the ancestral tablets and the sacred stones—the lords of the altars. Though the altars had a lord, my heart was elsewhere—how could I be disloyal? If one truly presides over the altars, who among the people within the state would not be a subject? To have no divided heart is Heaven’s decree. Prince Yi held the throne for fourteen years, yet those who plotted to recall you—were they not disloyal? Duke Zhuang had eight sons; if all were granted ranks, passersby would be encouraged to disloyalty. How could affairs be settled? You may do as you wish." He then received the command and hanged himself. When neither side harms the other, virtue and power converge in mutual return.

The *Shu* commentary says: People are the hosts of the spirits.

The *Yi* commentary says: In the nineteenth year of Duke Xi’s reign in *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, Duke Huan of Song sent Duke Wen of Zhu to sacrifice Prince Zi of Zeng at the altar of the *Ci* River’s spirit. Marshal Zi Yu said, "In ancient times, the six domestic animals were not used interchangeably in sacrifices. Minor affairs did not employ great sacrifices—how much less dare one use humans? Sacrifices are for the sake of people. People are the hosts of the spirits; if humans are used, who will receive the offerings? When Duke Huan of Qi preserved three perishing states, he bound them to the feudal lords. Righteous men still called this meager virtue. Now, in a single assembly, you have oppressed the lords of two states"—referring to the seizure of the Prince of Teng and the sacrifice of the Prince of Zeng—"and you employ them for licentious and benighted ghosts. How can you seek hegemony? It would be fortunate to escape ruin—I fear the state will perish." Zi Yu was Duke Gongzi Mu Yi of Song. The Sui River flows from the Bian into the Si, where there was a malevolent spirit. The Eastern Yi sacrificed humans to it. "The six domestic animals were not used interchangeably" means, for example, that one could not use a horse in sacrifices to the Horse Ancestor—how much less a human? Now, when the sage nurtures the people with the Dao, ghosts and spirits bestow blessings, and neither side harms the other. This may be called profound virtue.

**Chapter Sixty-One: The Great State as the Lower Reaches**
The *Yi* commentary says: In the thirtieth year of Duke Zhao’s reign in *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, You Ji of Zheng said to Shi Jingbo, a grandee of Jin, "When a small state serves a great one, it lies in reverently awaiting its commands. When a great state cherishes a small one, it lies in aiding what it lacks—this was the system of the former kings. To take precautions is all that is needed to maintain good relations." This is why a great state must urgently practice humility—it does not lie in using its greatness to control the small.

Thus, when a great state lowers itself to a small state, it wins the small state.

The *Yi* commentary says: In the fourteenth year of Duke Xiang’s reign in *The Spring and Autumn Annals*, a great state’s ability to pacify a small one is seen in how Jin, as the leader of the covenant, dealt with Wei, which had expelled its ruler and enthroned Prince Piao. Jin wished to punish its crime. The Marquis of Jin asked Zhonghang Xianzi for his opinion. Yan replied, "It would be better to stabilize it by following the situation. Attacking it may not achieve our aim and would only trouble the feudal lords." Historian Yi had said, "Follow its weightiness and pacify it." Zhong Hui had said, "Rescue the perishing and take the disordered; push away the perishing and secure the existing—this is the state’s Dao." The Marquis said, "Stabilize Wei and await the right moment." In winter, they assembled at Qi to deliberate on Wei. This is what is meant by a great state pacifying a small state.

As for a great state gathering small states, this refers to the myriad regions paying court and assembling without cease. Thus, the Xia founder Qi held the feast at Juntai (in Henan), the Shang founder Tang issued the decree at Jingbo (in Yanshi), the Zhou founder Wu swore the oath at Mengjin, King Cheng held the review at Qiyang, King Kang convened the court at Fenggong (in Huodu), King Mu assembled at Tushan (in Shouchun), Duke Huan of Qi led the campaign at Shaoling, and Duke Wen of Jin formed the covenant at Jiantu. In all these cases, the great states cherished those below, and the small states served those above—each found its proper place.

Gathering is for rectification; observing what is gathered reveals the nature of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. When the world is fractured and divided, the people resent, and even with sacrifices, it is as if there were no temple. Only when the king achieves great unity and filial virtue prevails can it be called possessing a temple.

chunks.original_text: 大国不能抚小国者，文十七年，如晋侯不能字育诸侯，强令於郑，郑子家与赵宣子书曰：古人有言，畏首畏尾，身其余几。 又曰：鹿死不择音。 小国之事大国也，德则其人，不德则其鹿也。 铤而走险，急何能择。 此言晋若虐命於郑，郑将庇於楚矣。 命之罔极，亦知亡矣。 将悉弊赋以待於修音叔，晋之境也，居大国之间，而从於强令，岂其罪也。 此由大国不能抚怀于小，将致其叛，故大国之于小国，当谦和以下之，柔静以怀之。 取言聚也，以聚於人也。 小国以下大国，则取大国。 义云：小国不能致礼竭诚奉事大国者，僖公二十一年，如宋人为鹿上之盟#2，以求诸侯于楚，楚人许之，宋公子目夷曰：小国争盟，祸也。 宋其亡乎，幸而后败。 及盟，目夷曰：祸其在兹乎。 君欲已甚，何以堪之。 於是楚执宋公以伐宋，冬会于亳，乃释之。 目夷曰：祸由未也，未足惩君，此小国不能事大国也。 夫小国能事大国者，如隐公元年三月，邾仪父盟于蔑鲁地，邾以附庸之，君未王命，故书名。 然其小国，能通大国，继好息民，书字以贵之是也。 朝聘者，大国适小国为聘，大事小也。 小国适大国为朝，小事大也。 继好，结信也。 谋事补阙，礼之大也。 孟子曰：唯仁者能以大事小。 汤事葛伯，文王事昆夷是也。 唯智者能以小事大，太王事熏鬻，勾践事吴是也。 大事小谓之乐天，小事大谓之畏天。 乐天者，保天下。 畏天者，保其国。 《诗》云：畏天之威，于时保之，此《周颂》美成王畏天之威，能安其太平也。 故或下以取，或下而取。 疏：《春秋》曰：师能左右之。 ○义云：《春秋》僖二十六年秋，宋叛楚而善於晋，楚令尹子玉、司马子西帅师伐宋，围缙，公以楚师伐齐取谷。 凡师能左右之曰以，谓进退在己。 置桓公之子雍於谷，以为鲁援。 楚申公叔侯戍之，桓公之子七人，为七大夫於楚，言齐孝公不能抚之故也。 二十八年，楚子使申叔去谷也，此言左右由己，取舍因时也。 大国不过欲兼畜人，小国不过欲入事人。 义云：小国求大国为援助者，《春秋》文十四年秋，郑伯与鲁公宴于棐，郑大夫归生子家赋《鸿雁》之什，取其哀恤鳏寡之义，使鲁侯恤之。 又赋《载驰》之四章，言郑国寡弱，取其小国有急，欲引大国以为援助是也。 两者各得其所欲，故大者宜为下。 义云：若大国不能为下，或会之以侈，示之以忲，人必离之。 夏桀为有仍之会，而民叛之。 商纣为黎之搜，东夷叛之。 周幽为太室之盟，戎夷叛之。 宋襄为鹿上之会，而诸侯叛之。 楚子为申之会，而人心去之。 怀不以德，绥不以礼，人人各有心，其可服乎。 道者万物之奥章第六十二 道者万物之奥。 疏：引《西升经》。 ○义云：《西升经》者，老君周昭王二十五年癸丑四月於终南之阴，尹喜草楼之内，授《道德》二经，既毕，欲西化流沙，尹喜问存三守一之方，习道修身之要，后以圣言编纂以升入太微、西化流沙之义。 《西升经》凡三十六章九百七十二句，四千二百七十八言，其旨与《道德经》相出入，言大道甚深甚奥，为虚无之渊薮也。 故立天子，置三公。 义云：四海之大，万有之殷，厥初生人，不可无主，故立天子以牧之。 天子者，尊事上帝，父事於天，母事於地，谓天之子也。
chunks.translated_text:
A great state that fails to nurture small states is exemplified in the seventeenth year of Duke Wen’s reign, when the Marquis of Jin could not cherish and foster the feudal lords but instead imposed harsh commands upon Zheng. Zijia of Zheng wrote to Zhao Xuanzi, saying: "The ancients had a saying, 'Fear the head, fear the tail—how much remains of the body?' They also said, 'A dying deer does not choose its cry.' When a small state serves a great state, if the great state possesses virtue, the small state becomes its people; if it lacks virtue, the small state becomes its deer. Pressed to the point of running risks, how can it choose? This means that if Jin imposes cruel commands upon Zheng, Zheng will seek refuge with Chu. If commands are without limit, it knows it will perish. It will exhaust its resources to await the arrival of Xiushu at Jin’s borders. Situated between great states and subjected to coercion, is this its fault? This arises from a great state’s failure to nurture and embrace the small, leading to their rebellion. Thus, a great state must humble itself and adopt a gentle, tranquil demeanor to win over small states. The term *qu* (取) means 'to gather,' that is, to gather others to oneself. When a small state submits to a great state, it gains the great state’s favor."

The *Commentary* states: "If a small state fails to offer utmost courtesy and sincerity in serving a great state," as in the twenty-first year of Duke Xi’s reign, when the people of Song formed the Covenant of Lushang to seek the allegiance of the feudal lords from Chu. Chu agreed, but Gongzi Muyi of Song said: "For a small state to contend for alliances is disaster. Is Song doomed? Fortunately, it suffered defeat later." When the covenant was made, Muyi said: "The disaster lies here. The ruler’s desires are excessive—how can he endure?" Thereupon, Chu seized the Duke of Song and attacked Song. In winter, they convened at Bo and released him. Muyi said: "The disaster arose from haste. It was not enough to admonish the ruler." This is an example of a small state’s failure to serve a great state.

When a small state successfully serves a great state, as in the first year of Duke Yin’s reign, when Yifu of Zhu formed an alliance at Mie (a territory of Lu), Zhu, though a dependent state, had not yet received the king’s mandate, so the *Spring and Autumn Annals* recorded his name. Yet as a small state, it was able to engage with a great state, maintain good relations, and bring peace to the people. The *Annals* honored it by recording its courtesy name—this is the proper way.

As for *chaoping* (朝聘): when a great state visits a small state, it is called *ping* (聘), for the great serves the small; when a small state visits a great state, it is called *chao* (朝), for the small serves the great. *Jihao* (继好) means to establish trust. Planning affairs and remedying deficiencies—this is the essence of ritual. Mencius said: "Only the humane can serve the small with the great," as when Tang served the Earl of Ge or King Wen served the Kun barbarians. "Only the wise can serve the great with the small," as when King Tai served the Xunyu or Goujian served Wu. Serving the small with the great is called "rejoicing in Heaven"; serving the great with the small is called "revering Heaven." Those who rejoice in Heaven preserve all under Heaven; those who revere Heaven preserve their state. The *Book of Songs* says: "Revere the majesty of Heaven, and thus preserve it in due time." This verse from the *Zhou Hymns* praises King Cheng for revering Heaven’s majesty and securing great peace.

Thus, some humble themselves to gain, while others gain by humbling themselves.

The *Commentary* states: The *Spring and Autumn Annals* says, "An army that can be directed left or right." The *Exegesis* explains: In the autumn of the twenty-sixth year of Duke Xi, Song rebelled against Chu and allied with Jin. Chu’s Chief Minister Ziyu and Marshal Zixi led forces to attack Song, besieging Jin. The Duke, with Chu’s army, attacked Qi and seized Gu. An army that can be directed left or right is said to act *yi* (以), meaning its advance or retreat is at its own discretion. The Duke placed Duke Huan’s son Yong in Gu as an ally for Lu. Shen Shuhou of Chu garrisoned it. Duke Huan had seven sons, who became seven grandees in Chu—this was because Duke Xiao of Qi could not nurture them. In the twenty-eighth year, the Viscount of Chu sent Shen Shu to withdraw from Gu. This illustrates that control lies with oneself, while taking or relinquishing depends on the times.

A great state desires nothing more than to care for others, while a small state desires nothing more than to serve others. The *Exegesis* states: When a small state seeks a great state’s aid, as in the autumn of the fourteenth year of Duke Wen, when the Earl of Zheng feasted with the Duke of Lu at Fei, Guisheng Zijia of Zheng recited the *Hongyan* ode, invoking its meaning of compassion for the widowed and orphaned, urging the Duke of Lu to show mercy. He also recited the fourth stanza of *Zaichi*, saying that Zheng, as a small and weak state in distress, sought to draw a great state’s support—this is the proper way. When both parties attain their desires, the greater should act with humility.

The *Exegesis* states: If a great state fails to act with humility, gathering others with arrogance and displaying excess, people will surely abandon it. Jie of Xia convened the assembly at Youreng, and the people rebelled. Zhou of Shang held the review at Li, and the Dongyi barbarians revolted. King You of Zhou formed the covenant at Taishi, and the Rong and Yi tribes rebelled. Duke Xiang of Song held the assembly at Lushang, and the feudal lords deserted him. The Viscount of Chu convened at Shen, and the people’s hearts turned away. If one does not embrace with virtue or pacify with ritual, each person will follow their own heart—how can they be subdued?

**Chapter Sixty-Two: The Dao as the Mystery of the Myriad Things**
The Dao is the mystery of the myriad things.

The *Commentary* cites the *Scripture of Western Ascent*. The *Exegesis* explains: The *Scripture of Western Ascent* was transmitted when Lord Lao, in the twenty-fifth year of King Zhao of Zhou (a *guichou* year), the fourth month, at the northern foot of Mount Zhongnan, within the thatched tower of Yin Xi, bestowed the two scriptures of the *Dao* and *Virtue*. Afterward, wishing to transform the Western Lands beyond the sands, Yin Xi inquired about the method of preserving the Three Ones and the essentials of cultivating the Dao and refining the body. Later, he compiled the sage’s words into the *Scripture of Western Ascent*, which conveys the meaning of ascending to the Great Subtlety and transforming the Western Lands. The *Scripture* comprises thirty-six chapters, 972 lines, and 4,278 characters. Its purport aligns with the *Scripture of the Dao and Virtue*, expounding the profound mystery of the Great Dao as the abyss of emptiness and nonbeing.

Thus, the Son of Heaven is established, and the Three Dukes are appointed.

The *Exegesis* states: The vastness of the four seas and the abundance of the myriad things—at the dawn of humanity, there could be no lordless realm. Thus, the Son of Heaven was established to govern them. The Son of Heaven reveres the Supreme Emperor, serves Heaven as a father, and serves Earth as a mother—he is called the Son of Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 一人不可以广理，置百官以临之，百官之长有三公焉。 《尚书□周官》云：其惟三公论道经邦。 太师者，智足以为泉源，行足以为仪表。 问焉则应，求焉则得，谓之太师，亦曰尚父。 太言大也，为王之师，安车青盖，金印紫绶。 太傅者，训也，保也，《大戴礼》云：傅天子以德义。 若天子无恩於父母，不惠于庶人，失礼於大臣，不中於制狱，皆太傅之失职也。 太保者，倚也，任也。 《大戴礼》云：天子处位不端，受书不敬，言语不序，声音不中律，进退即席，无升降揖让之礼，皆太保失职也。 复置三公：太尉、司徒、司空，主佐天子，理阴阳，亲万人，广教化，此其职也。 天工人其代之者，《书□咎繇谟》曰：一日二日万机，无旷庶官，天工人其代之。 旷，空也。 庶，众也。 居其位者，惟其人，非其人，则阙之。 言人代天理官，不可以天官为私，用非其材也。 虽有拱璧，以先驷马。 疏：《春秋》云：乘韦先牛十二犒师之类是也。 ○义云：《春秋》僖三十三年，晋师伐郑及滑，郑商人弦高将市於周，遇之，以乘韦先牛十二犒师，曰：寡君闻吾子将出师于弊邑，敢犒从者。 不腆弊赋，为从者之淹，止则具一日之积，行则备一夕之卫，且使遽告于郑，因有备焉。 其安易持章第六十四 不贵难得之货。

One person cannot govern broadly alone; thus, the hundred officials are appointed to oversee them, with the Three Dukes as their leaders. The *Missing Chapter on the Offices of Zhou* in the *Book of Documents* states: "Only the Three Dukes deliberate on the Dao and manage the state."

The Grand Preceptor possesses wisdom deep as a wellspring and conduct worthy of emulation. When consulted, he responds; when sought, he provides—thus he is called the Grand Preceptor, also known as the Venerated Father. "Grand" signifies greatness, for he serves as the king’s teacher. He rides in a secure carriage with a cyan canopy and bears a golden seal with purple ribbons.

The Grand Mentor is tasked with instruction and safeguarding. The *Rites of the Elder Dai* states: "He instills virtue and righteousness in the Son of Heaven." If the Son of Heaven shows no kindness to his parents, no benevolence to the common people, no propriety toward his ministers, or no impartiality in legal judgments, these are failures of the Grand Mentor’s duty.

The Grand Guardian serves as support and responsibility. The *Rites of the Elder Dai* states: "If the Son of Heaven sits improperly, receives documents irreverently, speaks out of order, sings off-key, or fails in the rituals of ascent, descent, bowing, and yielding, these are failures of the Grand Guardian’s duty."

Additionally, the Three Dukes—Grand Commandant, Minister of Education, and Minister of Works—assist the Son of Heaven in harmonizing yin and yang, caring for the people, and spreading moral instruction; these are their duties.

Heaven’s work is carried out by humans as its agents. The *Counsels of Gao Yao* in the *Book of Documents* states: "Day after day, the myriad affairs must not be neglected by the officials. Heaven’s work is carried out by humans as its agents." "Neglect" means vacancy; "myriad" means multitude. Those who occupy these positions must be the right persons; if not, the posts remain vacant. This means that humans act on Heaven’s behalf in governing offices and must not treat Heaven’s offices as private domains by appointing the unfit.

"Though one may offer a large jade disc before a team of four horses..."
*Annotation*: As in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, where cases like presenting four leather hides before twelve oxen to reward an army are recorded.
*Exegesis*: In the thirty-third year of Duke Xi in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, when the Jin army attacked Zheng and reached Hua, Zheng’s merchant Xian Gao, traveling to trade in Zhou, encountered them. He presented four leather hides and twelve oxen to reward the army, saying: "Our humble lord has heard that you, sirs, are marching against our state and ventures to offer this sustenance to your followers. Though our tribute is meager, for those who tarry, it provides a day’s provisions; for those who march, it secures a night’s defense. I have also sent a swift messenger to inform Zheng, that it may prepare." *(The following line, "Its ease and simplicity are upheld," from Chapter Sixty-Four of the* Scripture of the Dao and Virtue*, is unrelated and thus omitted.)*

Thus, the Son of Heaven was established to govern them. The Son of Heaven reveres the Supreme Emperor, serves Heaven as a father, and serves Earth as a mother—he is called the Son of Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 疏：外谓珠犀宝贝。 ○义云：珠者，大或径寸，光照十二乘，乃古人之所贵也。 犀者，南徼之外，有牛重千余斤，一角在鼻端，可以为宝，中断其角，有文通达成形象者。 有辟尘者，有辟水者，磨而服之，可解蛊毒之疾，鸡见之夜惊，故曰骇鸡。 犀亦今古所贵也。 金玉珍异，草木毛羽，众所奇重者，皆曰宝焉。 贝者，出东海中，如螺有文，有长尺者，可以为宝。 在海为介虫，居陆名猋，在水名蜬音甘。 古者货贝而宝龟，周有泉贝，到秦废贝而行钱。 贝字者，象形也。 今凡货贿赠赍赏赐琛赆，凡财之属，皆从贝矣。 古诗曰：积财为累愚，明财多累德也。 古有三币，珠玉为上，黄金为中，刀布为下，帝王以之御四海也。 古之善为道章第六十五 不以智治国，国之福。 注：偃息蕃魏，弄丸解难。 ○义云：偃息蕃魏者，段干木为魏文侯之师，以安静为先，道德为化，故偃息无事，而藩屏魏国矣。 偃者，偃仰也。 息，宴息也。 藩，篱屏也。 弄丸解难者，楚白公胜与大夫子西，两家举兵相伐，两家大夫曰：市南宜僚，陆沉之士也。 一人当五百人，并遣使往召之。 宜僚高枕安卧，以见二大夫之使，卧而不起，以两手弄丸不亡，承之以剑不动。 二大夫之使各还，具论宜僚之状，二大夫曰：高枕安卧者，示我无为也。 承之以剑不动者，兵不足恃也。 两手者，喻两家也。 丸者，形圆无为之物。 两手弄之不止者，俱止于困也。 明两家称兵不止，必至灭亡。 二大夫解兵而归，是两家难解也。 事见《庄子》也。 谓玄德，玄德深矣远矣，与物反矣，然后乃大顺。 义云：大顺者，本乎人情。 《礼记□礼运》篇曰：人情者，圣王之田也。 故圣王修义之柄，礼之序，以理人情。 以情为田，修礼以耕之，和刚柔也。 陈义以种之，树善道也。 讲学以耨之，存是去非也。 本人以聚之，合其所成也。 播乐以安之，感动使坚固也。 理国不以礼，犹无耜以耕也。 为礼不本於义，犹耕而不种也。 为义而不讲之以学，犹种之而不耨也。 讲之以学而不合之以七犹耨之而弗获也。 合之以仁而不安之以乐由获之而不食也。 安之以乐而不达之於顺，犹食之而不肥也。 夫四体既安，肤革充盈，人之肥也。 父子笃，兄弟睦，夫妇和，家之肥也。 大臣法，小臣廉，官职相序，君臣相正，国之肥也。 天子以德为车，以乐为御，诸侯以礼相与，大夫以法相序，士以信相考，百姓以睦相守，天下之肥也。 是谓大顺，故天子用民为顺，则天不爱其道，地不爱其宝，人不爱其情，众瑞出焉，顺之宝也。 用兵有言章第六十九 无兵。
